Responses.Author: Tenzing Choedar
Responses.Content:
Hi Meera,

 

Thank you for this wonderful post on the choice of vasopressors for the management of intraoperative hypotension. The beautiful illustrations you chose to represent each pressors will definitely help many of us remember as I can see that most of us are visual learners here. You provided an exceptional foundational framework elucidating the distinct pharmacodynamic mechanisms of various vasopressors and their corresponding physiological ramifications, while also facilitating a nuanced understanding of the clinical contexts in which their administration is most appropriate.

 

In conjunction with your preceding discussion, I fully concur with Adrian’s insights regarding the administration of vasopressors in the absence of adequate fluid resuscitation. It is imperative to ensure that the circulatory 'reservoir' is sufficiently replenished before deploying our beloved Avengers. As we have learned, the majority of anesthetic agents employed during general anesthesia induce vasodilation, either through direct action on vascular smooth muscle or by attenuating sympathetic nervous system activity. In addition, patients are fasting for more or at least 8 hours which could exacerbate our hemodynamics further with the use of GA.

 

I also wanted to add on to this wonderful topic, the use of Methlylene Blue (MB) in the state of vasoplegia when all vasopressors have been maxed out intraoperatively or postoperatively. The reason why I wanted to talk about this medication is because I have only seen it used once in my ICU in three years and I thought this patient was going to die. He was a post liver transplant patient in my coronary ICU who was bed spaced during the covid pandemic. He was maxed out on norepinephrine, epinephrine and vasopressin and was still hypotensive. One of my CICU fellow recommended the use of MB and it worked. Even our staff attending at that time was baffled and had no idea about the use of MB.

 

MB is primarily used to treat methemoglobinemia (FDA approved), a condition where Fe2+ of hemoglobin gets oxidized to Fe3+, reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin leading to cyanosis and hypoxemia. However, it also has an off label use of vasopressor mainly due to its

capacity to inhibit the body's inflammatory response by reducing nitric oxide (NO) production via selective inhibition of the enzyme inducible nitric oxide synthase and endothelial nitric oxide synthase. It also prevents NO from activating soluble guanylate cyclase, a key enzyme in the pathway that leads to smooth muscle relaxation, thereby helping restore vascular tone (Bistas & Sanghavi, 2023). Based on the current literature, MB is mainly used as a last resort to septic shock and vasoplegia refractory to catecholamines in liver transplant or cardiac surgeries.

A case study reported by Fischer et al. (2010) used a loading dose of MB at 2mg/kg over 30 minutes followed by continuous infusion over 6 hours at 0.5mg/kg/h for a patient during liver transplant surgery after graft reperfusion because the patient became profoundly hypotensive and after having difficulty maintaining a MAP above 65mmhg with epinephrine, norepinephrine and vasopressin plus fluid resuscitation. Shortly after the administration of MB, there was a significant improvement in hemodynamics, enabling the gradual tapering and eventual discontinuation of all pressors.

Furthermore, in the same case report, they point out multiple studies that have shown therapeutic benefit with low side effect profile, whether given prophylactically or with refractory shock, including – fewer dependencies on the pressors, quicker wean off pressors and reduction in mortality rate.

 

Dosage guideline as per Uptodate Lexidrug (2024) for refractory distributive shock/vasoplegia:

  • Bolus 1 to 2 mg/kg once daily for up to 3 doses, if needed; administer over 15 minutes to 6 hours.
  • Continuous infusion (0.25 to 2 mg/kg/hour for up to 48 hours) after administration of the initial bolus dose.

 

Some adverse effect to note are bluish-green discoloration of the urine (resolves after discontinuation), increasing the risk of serotonin syndrome if combine with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOI and TCI.

 

Ultimately, MB is seldom used and is not part of the routine standard of care and more studies needs to be done as there is paucity of information on the use of MB as first line therapy (Shanmugam, 2005). I think as an anesthesia assistant, it’s important to know that there are more drugs to help with vasopressor therapy when standard of care medications fail to achieve hemodynamic stability, just like how I felt when caring for my patient who was very hypotensive despite all medical therapy.

 

 

Reference:

 

Bistas, E., & Sanghavi, D. K. (2023). Methylene blue. In StatPearls. StatPearls Publishing. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557593/

 

Fischer, G. W., Bengtsson, Y., Scarola, S., & Cohen, E. (2010). Methylene blue for vasopressor-resistant vasoplegia syndrome during liver transplantation. Journal of Cardiothoracic and Vascular Anesthesia, 24(3), 463-466. https://doi.org/10.1053/j.jvca.2008.07.015

 

Shanmugam, G. (2005). Vasoplegic syndrome—the role of methylene blue. European Journal of Cardio-Thoracis Surgery, 28(5), 705-710. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejcts.2005.07.011

 

UpToDate Inc. (2024). Methlylene Blue. Lexi-Drugs, UpToDate Lexidrug. Retrieved October 10, 2024, https://online-lexi-com.uhn.idm.oclc.org/lco/action/doc/retrieve/docid/patch_f/7279?cesid=33y1FS0NmO3&searchUrl=%2Flco%2Faction%2Fsearch%3Fq%3Dmethylene%2Bblue%26t%3Dname%26acs%3Dtrue%26acq%3Dmethylene%2Bblue#

Responses.Author: Meera Sathananthan
Responses.Content:
Hi Adrian and Tenzing,
Thank you both for your thoughtful contributions! I appreciate the discussion on optimizing fluid status—it’s such a key part of maximizing our arsenal of pressors.
Adrian, your points about fluid administration and the study involving pregnant patients undergoing spinal anesthesia were really insightful. A timely fluid bolus can help minimize hypotensive episodes and lessen our reliance on pressors. While pressors can be effective, they might just be a Band-Aid fix if the underlying cause of hypotension is hypovolemia.
Tenzing, I found your insights on Methylene Blue (MB) particularly interesting! Thank you for sharing your personal experience - it adds a very unique perspective. That was very innovative thinking on that fellow's part! I have not yet encountered MB in my clinical experience and hadn’t considered MB as a potential addition to our toolkit for managing vasoplegia, so your overview was really helpful. It’s great to have options like this when traditional pressors don’t quite cut it.
Thanks again for the great discussion! I initially wanted to explore the different causes of intraoperative hypotension, but there was so much to cover with vasopressors that I had to pivot. It’s exciting to delve into these strategies together and enhance our holistic approach to management.
Sincerely,
Meera

Responses.Author: Meera Sathananthan
Responses.Content:
Hi all!

I came across a nice decision tree for diagnosing the cause of acute hypotension. As we mentioned, understanding the cause of a patient's intraoperative hypotension helps us determine the best course of action for optimal management, whether it is fluid resuscitation, vasopressor use, inotropic support or a combination of different techniques.

Figure 1: Decision tree for diagnosing acute hypotension (1)

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam

Question: Question 17: From your experience, describe an adverse event resulting from any drug group covered in the pharmacology section.

Responses.Author: Deena Kurilsky
Responses.Content:
Adverse reaction to sedation with propofol:

A 72-year-old female came into the emergency department with a humorous fracture requiring a sedation for a closed reduction and realignment. Patient was previously healthy with no known drug allergies and an elevated BMI.

 

Events prior to the sedation:

  • On review of the patient’s medical history, the patient’s elevated BMI was a concern for potential risk of respiratory complications.
  • An airway assessment was completed. The patient had a good mouth opening and thyromental distance, good neck mobility and was classified as a mallampati class III. She denied any diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea.
  • Baseline vitals were established, and pre-oxygenation was initiated via nasal prongs.

 

Procedural sedation:

  • The emergency physician administered a dose of fentanyl 25mcg for analgesia followed by a bolus of propofol of 50mg, after 1 minute the patient remained awake and alert.
  • A second bolus of 50mg of propofol was administered and shortly after the patient became drowsy with a reduced level of consciousness. Vitals remained stable.

 

Adverse Event:

  • Approximately 2 minutes after the second bolus of propofol the patient began to exhibit a decreased respiratory effort and respiratory rate, SpO2 was 92%. The oxygen was increased from 4-6L and a jaw thrust was initiated to relieve any airway obstruction.
  • The blood pressure reading that followed indicated the patient was hypotensive. The patient now completely apneic began to desaturate. Bag-mask ventilation was initiated for a couple minutes, until regular respiratory efforts were maintained by the patient.
  • The patient’s blood pressure remained labile, despite stimulation from the arm reduction. This required a bolus of phenylephrine 100mcg to normalize. No further sedation was required to finish the procedure. Within the following 10 minutes the patient was fully awake and alert, protecting their airway with stable vitals.

 

Key Observations:

  • Having an emergency plan for intervention in the case of an adverse reaction is important. In the sedation room we were prepared with oxygen equipment, suction, bag-valve mask, an oral airway and intubation equipment as well as phenylephrine available if needed. 
    • Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 agonist and potent peripheral vasoconstrictor; this makes it a very effective drug to treat hypotension (Pardo, 2022). In this case, the vasodilator effects of propofol were counteracted with phenylephrine to normalize the patient’s blood pressure.

    • An alternative medication to considered for hypotension during sedation is ephedrine. Ephedrine is a noncatecholamine sympathomimetic that acts at both alpha and beta receptors. Its effects on arterial blood pressure are useful in the hypotensive patient especially when accompanied by bradycardia. In this case, the patient’s heart rate remained normal with only transient decreases in blood pressure (Pardo, 2022).

    • If the analgesic effects had been prolonged or a larger dose of fentanyl had been administered, it may have been useful to have naloxone (narcan) available. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used in the reversal of opioid-induced respiratory depression (Pardo, 2022). Had the synergistic respiratory depression of fentanyl and propofol lasted longer requiring prolonged manual ventilation, a dose of naloxone could have helped to reverse the effects quicker.

  • Sedative selection is important when considering patients risk factors. I will discuss the medications used in this scenario and give insight into an alternative option.
    • Propofol was administered alongside fentanyl. Propofol, a hypnotic agent with no analgesia, is often used in sedative procedures for its quick onset and short duration of action. Propofol is a known respiratory depressant with a narrow therapeutic range (Pardo, 2022). During this sedation, the bolus of propofol caused a decrease in tidal volume and respiratory rate and ultimately an apneic event. The hypotensive episode was caused by the vasodilatory effects that propofol has on the arterial and venous circulation, this required the use of phenylephrine as an intervention to normalize the blood pressure. (Pardo, 2022). An alternative sedative to consider in the future for this patient is ketamine. Ketamine has analgesic properties, but it also maintains respiratory drive as well as the upper airway and is more hemodynamically stable (Pardo, 2022). This would make it a safer option for an elderly patient with a large BMI that obstructs easily with sedation.

 

  • The following are additional adjuncts to therapy that could have been beneficial.
    • High flow oxygen therapy, as an alternative to nasal prongs. The higher flows and resulting dead space washout help to maintain oxygenation during prolonged periods of apnea. In turn, decreasing the likelihood and need for manual ventilation.

    • Use of end-tidal CO2 nasal prongs can provide earlier warning signs of respiratory depression before the onset of a hypoxic event. In the study published by Deitch et al. (2010) capnography decreased the rate of hypoxic events associated with propofol sedation and improved patient safety.


References:

 

Deitch, K., Miner, J., Chudnofsky, C. R., Dominici, P., & Latta, D. (2010). Does end tidal CO2 monitoring during emergency department procedural sedation and analgesia with propofol decrease the incidence of hypoxic events? A randomized, controlled trial. Annals of Emergency Medicine, 55(3), 258-264. 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2009.07.030

 

Pardo, M. C., Jr. (Ed). (2022). Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed.). Elsevier

Responses.Author: Janet Rozek
Responses.Content:
Deena, great review of a real case! Sounds like you did everything you could with the information you had regarding, patients age, anesthetic needs, and approach.  I agree with your suggestions for therapy including:
  •  -the use of ephedrine for the hypotension
  • monitoring end tidal CO2 with nasal prongs and supplemental oxygen
Here is a little example from my experience:

Many years ago, I recall working in the OR during the start of a cesarean section for failure to progress. The patient had an epidural insitu for her labour so anesthesia decided to load the epidural with lidocaine and epimorph to optimize block for surgery.  Within 10-15 minutes after bolus of medication, the patient was experiencing signs and symptoms of a High regional block. The patients signs and symptoms included severe hypotension, weakness and numbness in arms, patient was feeling very short of breathe and having some sedation effects. Anesthesia quickly identified the urgency and the Anesthesiologist and I were able to act quickly and safely. The surgery had begun, so baby was being delivered imminently, patient was needing  oxygen and bag mask ventilation to assist her breathing. Patient needed rapid IV fluids and a phenylephrine infusion to help support her blood pressure. We continued to manually bag patient with CO2 monitoring throughout case, all emergency intubation drugs and equipment was prepped and ready in case of any further decline of patient. Uterus was already displaced in the start of the case to ensure proper blood flow to mom and baby. In this case the patient did not decline any further, by the end of the case patient was starting to become more alert and oriented to where she was.  Patient did not become bradycardic and did not require intubation. Overall, patient was stabilized in the operating room before going to recovery room with her baby.

Responses.Author: Deena Kurilsky
Responses.Content:
Thank you for sharing this experience in the operating room during a cesarian section. Early recognition of the signs and symptoms of a high regional block was vital in managing this situation. I wonder if the baby had not been delivered when the phenylephrine infusion was initiated if a different vasopressor such as ephedrine or norepinephrine may have been used instead?

 

I have not had experience with a high or complete spinal block, so I wanted to add some information collected from an article.

 

Patients will experience symptoms based on the level of the anesthetic spread. Hypotension and bradycardia can result from vasodilation and reduced venous return. Once the abdominal and intercostal muscles are blocked the patient will experience shortness of breath and may feel numbness or weakness as you stated in their upper body.  Respiratory arrest will occur if the diaphragm is paralysed leading to loss of consciousness and further decline. Supportive care in the form of supplemental oxygen and intubation if needed, as well as fluids with vasopressors to support the maternal blood pressure is important as the pregnant woman cannot withstand prolonged hypotension or hypoxia without damage to herself and the infant (Asfaw et al, 2020) 

 

Early recognition of these symptoms is important and changing the position of the patient can affect the progression of the block. If the patient has a progressing high spinal that has not progressed to a total spinal. it is not recommended to place the patient in the Trendelenburg position. Placing in the Trendelenburg position will result in a higher block and could progress to a total spinal (Asfaw et al, 2020)

 

Asfaw, G., & Eshetie, A. (2020). A case of total spinal anesthesia. International journal of surgery case reports.76, 237–239. http://doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.ijscr.2020.09.177

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content: Thanks, Deena and Janet, for sharing your experience. This is the best way to draw connections between theories and practice. In both cases, I agree with the use of Phenylephrine and capnography monitoring. Phenylephrine is our first choice of pressor to temper hypotension without bradycardia. If the patient also presents bradycardia, we can use Ephedrine as it will increase both blood pressure and heart rate. Regarding capnography, it is a required monitoring for any type of anesthesia. As anesthesia assistants, we always use capnography not only for general and regional anesthesia but also for procedural sedation. I also want to share an adverse event that happened a couple of years ago.  It was a case of a full-blown anaphylactic reaction to Rocuronium in a living-related liver donor, right after induction.  We ended up canceling the case (and also the living-related liver recipient’s case) and sent the patient intubated to the intensive care unit. When we have an allergic reaction in the operating room (OR), the triggers that first come to my mind are latex, antibiotics, and muscle relaxants. We don't have a lot of latex-containing equipment/supplies in the OR nowadays.  In anesthesia, I can only think of the sterile gloves and the pulmonary artery catheter containing latex.  It is always important to remind the surgical team to change to non-latex sterile gloves during anaphylaxis.  Regarding muscle relaxants, Succinylcholine is the most common offender, and Rocuronium is also identified as producing an increased risk as a triggering agent in the non-depolarizing class, even though it does not release histamine.

Responses.Author: Dan Chen
Responses.Content: Thank you for the insightful story, Deena. You’ve provided a comprehensive account of how propofol, despite its efficacy, can present challenges with respiratory and hemodynamic stability, especially in elderly patients with elevated BMIs. Your proactive management of these complications—utilizing phenylephrine for hypotension and bag-mask ventilation for apnea—really highlights the importance of being well-prepared for potential sedation-related complications. To further elaborate on your alternative option of ketamine, it not only presents a safer choice for elderly patients with higher BMIs but also shows significant advantages for pediatric populations. At SickKids Emergency, ketamine is the first-choice drug for conscious sedation, and we rigorously monitor end-tidal CO2 with nasal prongs and provide supplemental oxygen to ensure safety. Ketamine's unique pharmacologic properties make it highly suitable for conscious sedation. As a nonbarbiturate phencyclidine derivative, ketamine creates a "dissociative sedation" rather than typical conscious sedation. This dissociative state provides profound analgesia, amnesia, and preservation of protective airway reflexes, along with cardiopulmonary stability (Mistry & Nahata, 2005). Ketamine’s ability to preserve spontaneous respirations and its hemodynamic stability (due to its indirect sympathomimetic effect) make it especially valuable for patients with compromised cardiovascular or respiratory function. However, it’s essential to consider potential complications such as increased salivary secretions and emergence phenomena, which can be managed with the coadministration of anticholinergics and benzodiazepines (Mistry & Nahata, 2005). Emergence phenomena are a well-known side effect of ketamine sedation, particularly noticeable during the recovery phase. These effects include vivid dreams, hallucinations, a floating sensation, delirium, agitation, and feelings of unease or discomfort (dysphoria). Ketamine's strong sedative properties can disrupt sensory processing in the brain, leading to these unsettling mental experiences after sedation. Certain groups, such as patients over 16 years of age and females, are more prone to experiencing these phenomena. The cause is believed to be ketamine's interference with auditory and visual pathways, resulting in misinterpretation of sensory inputs. This creates a dissociative state where reality can seem distorted, often manifesting as confusing or frightening experiences (Mistry & Nahata, 2005). In my experience working with patients who have undergone ketamine sedation, I’ve seen firsthand how emergence phenomena not only cause discomfort for the child but also create distress for parents or caregivers who witness their child in this state. It’s important to manage these effects carefully, not just for the patient’s well-being but also for the peace of mind of those around them. Administering a benzodiazepine like midazolam or diazepam alongside ketamine can help mitigate these effects by reducing the severity of hallucinations and agitation, making the recovery process smoother (Mistry & Nahata, 2005). Reference: Mistry, R. B., & Nahata, M. C. (2005). Ketamine: A novel agent for pediatric sedation. _Pharmacotherapy: The Journal of Human Pharmacology and Drug Therapy_, _25_(8), 1104-1114. https://doi.org/10.1592/phco.2005.25.8.1104

Responses.Author: Deena Kurilsky
Responses.Content:
Thank you for sharing your insights, Dan. Your approach to managing emergence phenomena with benzodiazepines for patient comfort is very important. I haven’t worked with pediatrics in a while, but I’m curious about your experience. Have you observed any changes in the duration of action or time to awakening in children who receive both ketamine and benzodiazepines together?

 

Reflecting on my clinical experience, I was reminded of the use of ketamine for dental sedations at Mount Sinai. We conduct a weekly dental clinic in the operating room specifically for developmentally delayed patients requiring a general anesthetia, many of whom are non-verbal and can sometimes be quite combative. This makes it extremely challenging to gain their cooperation for intravenous insertions, which can be traumatic for both the patients and their caregivers. Using oral ketamine as a pathway to an inhaled induction for general anesthesia has proven to be effective, resulting in a better experience for both the patient and their caregivers. Ketamine proves to be very versatile in vulnerable populations.

Responses.Author: Kelly Gram
Responses.Content: Janet, very interesting case with the high regional block. I was working in ortho today and I assisted the anesthesiologist with a spinal which she used bupivicaine mixed with epimorph. This triggered a very interesting discussion regarding the risk of respiratory depression specifically with the use of epimorph. I learned today that whenever a patient is given epimorph, the standard of care is to monitor the patient very closely, usually APS follows, in hospital for at least 24 hours post administration as it is known to produce biphasic respiratory depression. This is because morphine is not metabolized in the CSF thus has prolonged activity at the receptor site.  It must be absorbed into plasma before being metabolized and excreted.  Although spinal vs epidural epimorph differs in terms of dosage and absorption, your post had me question whether this mom would have been at risk for a secondary phase respiratory depression? This prompted me to look up the mechanism for why the risk of respiratory depression can be so delayed specifically when given intrathecally.  I found this article that explains that intrathecal epimorph can cause respiratory depression by way of rostral spread and slow penetration into the brainstem. This supra spinal redistribution of morphine leads to delayed activation of μ-opioid receptors on the medulla that are responsible for the second phase or delayed respiratory depression that can happen up to 24 hours post administration. Even though the concentration of epimorph would be reduced over time, these μ-opioid receptors are very sensitive to epimorph. Thankfully the second of the two phases of respiratory depression is generally less pronounced likely due to lower CSF drug concentrations but when it happens overnight in a low monitoring environment, the results could be catastrophic.  Sultan, P., Gutierrez, M.C. & Carvalho, B. Neuraxial Morphine and Respiratory Depression. _Drugs_ **71**, 1807–1819 (2011). https://doi.org/10.2165/11596250-000000000-00000

Responses.Author: Ryan Smith
Responses.Content:
Deena Thank you for the reminder that one of the pillars of anesthesia, propofol, with a relatively good safety profile and proliferative use still needs to be handled with caution and vigilance. I'm reminded of a reduction in the trauma bay I will never forget and have passed on to many colleagues and students:
  • 55 male involved in a motorcycle MVC
  • Significant trunk road rash, broken ribs, small pnuemothorax and a closed femur fracture (standard fair in my beloved trauma room).
The patient was treated with fentanyl by EMS and remained very stable through initial assessment, GCS 15 and pleasant throughout.  An initial reduction of the femur was to be performed in the trauma bay before heading to CT scan (again standard fare).  Induction dose for the femur reduction was 120mg ketamine (he was a large gentleman).  Within 20 seconds the patient went into the most impressive trismus I have ever witnessed, and upper body rigidty, abdominal rectus rigidty and obviously apnea.  Unfortunately it was COVID era within "minimal staffing" in our enclosed trauma bay (anesthesia was outside the see through doors at the head of a bed with the passenger of the MVC).  We yelled for any available paralytic and it took aprx 60 seconds to draw it up and hand it into the room.  The rocuronium was given and a further 60 seconds was needed before I could finally bag mask ventilate the patient.  The desaturation was significant with concomitant bradycardia however CPR was never indicated (barely).  The patient was intubated and recovered without any apparent neurological deficit.     The event drastically heightened my awareness of the potential dangers of the ever more popular Ketamine and the absolute necessity of having a NMB very close at hand for inductions.

Responses.Author: Tenzing Choedar
Responses.Content:
Hi Deena and everyone else that contributed to this discussion post,

 

Thank you for sharing your insights and reminding us that, even with a comprehensive understanding of the pharmacodynamics of anesthetic agents, adverse effects can still occur. This underscores the fact that, despite adherence to established guidelines and protocols, individual patient responses to medications can vary significantly. It highlights the critical importance of preoperative assessment and being prepared for any potential emergency, regardless of the controlled nature of the clinical setting. I am starting to appreciate Phoebe’s favorite quote by Benjamin Franklin, “By failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail” even more now.

 

One key lesson I’ve learned from my limited experience in the Cardiac Catheterization Lab and Coronary ICU is that managing procedural or deep sedation can be far more challenging than managing general anesthesia. With general anesthesia, the airway is already secured through tracheal intubation, allowing the focus to shift to maintaining hemodynamics and ensuring adequate sedation. In contrast, procedural sedation requires constant vigilance over both airway management and the patient’s hemodynamic stability, making it a more complex balancing act.

 

I’d like to share one event that sort of made me dislike the medication dexmedetomidine.

I had a patient who was undergoing a percutaneous transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVI) under conscious sedation with local anesthetic. This elderly patient from what I remember did not have any underlying renal or hepatic disease. His LV function was normal although with hypertrophic concentric remodeling due to chronic systolic overload from aortic stenosis. I was the circulating RN and the anesthesia fellow chose his conscious sedation strategy with a bolus of fentanyl and dexmedetomidine followed by dexmedetomidine infusion (1-1.5mcg/kg/h). The procedure which normally last about 45 minutes to an hour lasted about two hours due to a minor vascular complication which required me to hold the groin on the operating table for good 15 minutes. We transferred the patient over to the recovery unit without any problem and his blood pressure on the arterial line was reading around 90/60mmhg. Everything seemed fine and we handed the patient over to the recovery RN. He was mentating fine although a bit drowsy, GCS 14. After 30 minutes, I was called by the recovery RN and informed me that the patient’s BP is slow to rise with lowest around 70/40 and HR in the 50s, and continued to stay around that region. We ruled out all the possible causes - bleed, tamponade, stroke, valve dislodgment etc. Nothing obvious noted on POCUS of the heart. One common complication of TAVI is the widening of QRS and the high chance of going into complete heart block. Pt’s ECG was within baseline from pre-tavi although more brady. Ultimately, we decided it was probably the dexmedetomidine and the decision was made to start levophed infusion and transfer to CICU for monitoring. 

 

As great of a drug dexmedetomidine is—providing analgesic and sedative effect without respiratory depression, one must remember that it is a sympatholytic agent that can cause bradycardia and hypotension (Bokoch & Su, 2023). Furthermore, the elimination half time is 2 to 3 hours (Rathmell & Dahan, 2022). Iirola et al. (2012) conducted a study to assess the pharmacokinetic profile of dexmedetomidine in critically ill patients requiring infusion longer than 48 hours. They found that pharmacokinetics of dexmedetomidine after long-term infusion remained consistent with those observed in shorter-term studies. However, elderly patients experience reduced drug clearance, and those with low plasma albumin levels have an increased volume of distribution, both of which contribute to a prolonged elimination half-life. We learned from Rathmell & Dahan (2022) that dexmedetomidine is highly protein bound (>90%).

 

Therefore, in my case, Dexmedetomidine was probably the culprit due to the continuous infusion for two hours increasing the context sensitive half time and providing sympatholytic effects leading to hypotension and bradycardia. Perhaps my patient also had low albumin levels which contributed to its pharmacodynamic effects. Perhaps this

patient was also more dependent on HR for cardiac output as patients with hypertrophy of the LV can have reduced diastolic filling volume. Whatever the reason is, I have grown to be more cautious with this medication because it has happened multiple times in the cathlab recovery unit as well as in my ICU.

 

Reference: 

Iirola, T., Ihmsen, H., Laitio, R., Kentala, E., Aantaa, R., Kurvinen, J., Scheinin, M., Schwilden, H., Schüttler, J., & Olkkola, K. T. (2012). Population pharmacokinetics of dexmedetomidine during long-term sedation in intensive care patients. British Journal of Anaesthesia: BJA, 108(3), 460-468. https://doi.org/10.1093/bja/aer441

Bokoch, M. P., & Su, P. P. (2023). Intravenous anesthetics. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 107-124). Elsevier.

 

Rathmell, J. P., & Dahan, A. (2022). Intravenous sedatives and hypnotics. In P. Flood, J. P. Rathmell, & R. D. Urman (Eds.), Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in Anesthetic Practice (6th ed., pp. 206-245). Wolters Kluwer.

 

Cheers, 

Tenzing

Responses.Author: Deena Kurilsky
Responses.Content:
Hi Tenzing & Ryan

 

Tenzing, thank you for sharing your clinical experience with dexmedetomidine in the cardiac cath lab. I appreciate the time you took to talk about the pharmokinetics of dexmedetomidine including its advantages and disadvantages.  Your experience really highlighted the complexity of using sedatives especially in elderly patients with specific cardiac issues. 

 

Given my limited experience with cardiac patients, I’m interested in your insights. What types of sedation are you typically used to seeing used in the cardiac cath lab?

 

 

Ryan, thank you for the reminder of the potential risks associated with ketamine. Your experience really highlighted the unpredictability of patient-drug reactions and the necessity of being prepared to handle complications during induction.

 

Thank you for your posts!

Question: Question 18: Which types of drugs should be continued preoperatively? Which types of drugs should be discontinued preoperatively?

Responses.Author: Shawn Page
Responses.Content:
MEDICATIONS TO DISCONTINUE

 

Something interesting came up in the research for this assignment. The use os herbal supplements kept coming up.  Many popular supplements kept reappearing.

Name

Perioperative effects

Recommendations

Echinacea

Hepatotoxicity, interference with immune suppressive therapy (ie. Organ transplants)

Discontinue as far in advance as possible

Ephedra

Ephedrine like SNS stimulation with increased HR, increased BP, dysrhythmias, MI, CVA

Discontinue at least 24 hours pre Sx

Ginkgo

Inhibits platelet aggregation factor

Discontinue at least 7 days prior (irreversible)

Ginseng

Hypoglycemia, inhibition of platelet aggregation and coagulation cascade

Discontinue at least 7 days prior Sx

Kava

GABA-mediated hypnotic effect and may decrease MAC

Discontinue at least 24 hours prior Sx

St. John’s Wart

Inhibits serotonin, norepi and dopamine reuptake by neurons

Discontinue at least 5 days prior

Valerian

GABA -mediated hypnotic effects, may decrease MAC, benzodiazepine like withdrawl symptoms

Taper dose weeks before Sx

(Morgan, G., 2002)

 

 

 

Antiplatelets

Antiplatelets ie. ASA, clopidogrel are often prescribed in the treatment for primary and secondary MI prevention (Urology, D.,2009). Platelet primary function is to stop hemorrhage after trauma or vascular injury.  ASA is the most common antiplatelet prescribed, and it works by irreversibly inactivating the COX-1 enzyme, and as a result the pathway for thromboxane A2 synthesis is blocked.  Since this is a potent platelet aggregator (as well as a vasoconstrictor), the bodies ability to develop clots is lost.  (Urology, D., 2009)

ASA begins to act within 30 mins of administration and it’s effects are irreversible.  The average lifespan of a platelet is 8-10 days.  If ASA is abruptly discontinued a rebound effect may occur.  The intended therapy is no longer being provided but also an abnormally high level of thromboxane A@ occurs which increases a patients risk or cardiac events, TIS/CVA, and death. If intra-op bleeding occurs the patient should be treated with tranexamic acid (TXA), as well as a platelet infusion (Urology, D. 2009)  A prophylactic dose of TXA may also be given intra-op.

 

ACE Inhibitors

The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is important to target in the treatment for hypertension.  ACE inhibitors block the conversion of angiotensin 1 into 2. Angiotensin 2 acts to narrow blood vessels, therefore it can increase blood pressure (Salim, F., 2020)

A 2019 study found that patients who use ACE inhibitors have a possibility of hypotension intraoperatively, especially within the first 30 mins of the procedure (Salin, F. 2020), however the still remains great debate about if and when to stop these pre-operatively.

 

 

MEDICATIONS TO CONTINUE

 

Beta Blockers

Beta blockers are an important tool  in preventing arrythmias.  The discontinuation of these greatly increases a patients chance of developing an arrythmia, therefore they should no, and are safe not to stop.  Beat blockers block the effect of epinephrine to maintain heart rate.  Practitioners need to be aware if a patient is on this, and the HR may not increase in cases of shock, or painful stimuli.  The also have the heart contract with less force, and it also acts as a vasodilator. There should be no interaction with anesthetic agents, or common intra-op medications so they are safe to continue (Irizarry-Alvarado, J., 2017).

 

Insulin

 

Stress from surgery and anesthesia increases the secretion of counterregulatory hormones ie. Glucagon.  This process decreases insulin secretion and peripheral glucose utilization, and also increases insulin resistance (Dogra, P. 2024).  Uncontrolled hyperglycemia introperatively in creases production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (Dogra, P. 2024).  Patients are NPO for surgery so glucose monitoring is essential.

Long acting insulin should be decreased by 20-25% the evening before. Intermediate acting insulin, the patient should take their usual dose the night before, but decrease the dose by 50% the morning of surgery.  This being said, institutions should create their own sliding-scale for insulin dosages.  Critically ill diabetic patients should have an insulin drip intra-operatively (Dogra, P., 2024).

 

 

Dogra P, Anastasopoulou C, Jialal I. Diabetic Perioperative Management. [Updated 2024 Jan 25]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK540965/

 

Irizarry-Alvarado, J. (2017). Perioperative management of beta blockers and other antiarrhythmic medications. Current clinical pharmacology. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28847276/

 

Morgan, J., G. Edward, Mikhail, M. S., & Murray, M. J. (2002). Clinical anesthesiology (3rd ed.). Lange.

 

Salim, F., Khan, F., Nasir, M., Ali, R., Iqbal, A., & Raza, A. (2020, January 9). Frequency of intraoperative hypotension after the induction of anesthesia in hypertensive patients with preoperative angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. Cureus. https://doi.org/10.7759%2Fcureus.6614

 

Urology, D. of. (2009). Antiplatelet drugs and the perioperative period: What every ... : Indian Journal of Urology. LWW. https://doi.org/10.4103%2F0970-1591.56174

Responses.Author: Teresa Nguyen
Responses.Content:
Hi Shawn,

 

Thank you for your insightful response. I found it interesting that you also included herbs and naturopathic medicine as these can be important considerations for pre-operative patients.

 

In your answer, one of the medications to discontinue pre-operatively included acetylsalicylic acid (ASA). However, you also stated that abrupt discontinuation may cause a rebound effect and the intended therapy is no longer present. My question is, can you further explain what the rebound effect entails? If a patient requires surgery and must stop receiving ASA, what interventions would be done to address the rebound effect?  

 

A study by Maulaz et al. (2005) states that discontinuing aspirin therapy may increase risk of ischemic stroke in patients who have several cardiovascular risk factors. Withholding antiplatelet therapy pre-operatively in patients with ischemic heart disease may not always be beneficial (Maulaz, 2005).

 

I would also like to share some insight on another category of medications. Patients receiving psychotropic medications are generally instructed to continue treatment: antidepressants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI), and antipsychotic medications (Karunarathna, n.d.). Abrupt cessation may lead to withdrawal symptoms and exacerbate psychiatric conditions (Karunarathna, n.d.). Additionally, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) should be stopped two weeks before anesthesia, as they can interact with anesthetics, potentially causing hypertensive crisis (Karunarathna, n.d.). Lithium should also be stopped 72 hours prior to surgery to avoid lithium toxicity or interference with anesthetics (Karunarathna, n.d.).

 

 

References

 

Karunarathna, I., Bandara, S., Jayawardana, A., De Alvis, K., Gunasena, P., Hapuarachchi, T.,

Ekanayake, U., Rajapaksha, S., Gunawardana, K., Aluthge, P., & Gunathilake, S. (n.d.). Pre-operative medication management: adjusting psychotropic and antiplatelet therapies for surgical patients. 

 

Maulaz, A.B., Bezerra, D.C., Michel, P., & Bogousslavsky, J. (2005). Effect of discontinuing aspirin

therapy on the risk of brain ischemic stroke. Arch Neurol, 62(8), 1217-1220.  doi:10.1001/archneur.62.8.1217

Responses.Author: Minna Jin
Responses.Content:
Hi Shawn, 

Thank you for your detailed breakdown of both herbal supplements and conventional medicines. It is interesting to see how herbal supplements interact with some conventional medicines.

Among these medications, I am particularly interested in the protocols related to insulin therapy preoperatively. Thank you for illustrating the different guidelines around preoperative adjustments for long-acting and intermediate-acting insulin. I am also curious about whether the management of insulin therapy would differ for patients with type 1 diabetes versus those with type 2 diabetes preoperatively. Apparently, patients with type 1 diabetes must continue receiving basal insulin even while fasting to prevent the development of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperglycemia (Sreedharan et al., 2023). Other than that, the preoperative adjustment of different types of insulin slightly differs between type 1 and type 2 diabetes. As you mentioned, long-acting insulin should be reduced by 25% the evening before surgery. However, short-acting insulin should be withheld on the morning of surgery for type 2 diabetes, while correctional rapid-acting insulin can be given to treat hyperglycemia in type 1 diabetes (Pardo, 2023). Despite the protocols, the management of insulin therapy should always be based on patients’ blood glucose levels. 

Sreedharan, R., Khanna, S., & Shaw, A. (2023). Perioperative glycemic management in adults presenting for elective cardiac and non-cardiac surgery. Perioperative Medicine, 12(13). https://doi.org/10.1186/s13741-023-00291-w

Pardo, M. C. (2023). Preoperative evaluation. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 195-220). Elsevier.

Responses.Author: Kurt Protacio
Responses.Content:
Thanks Shawn for the information regarding what to continue and discontinue preoperatively. I found it very refreshing as I am familiar with some of the drugs. As a nurse who works in Coronary Intensive Care, we often see physicians ordering to hold antiplatelets such as Clopedigrel (Plavix) five days before surgery, and/or anticoagulants such as Warfarin at least five days before cardiovascular surgery, or bridging to intravenous Heparin, which is shorter-acting and can be stopped an hour before surgery (depending on the policies of the institution). Acetylsalicylic acid (Aspirin) is an interesting one; it really depends on the situation. During emergent, life-threatening situations such as a ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), Aspirin is given in bolus doses to combat platelet aggregation in the blocked arteries, and in some cases, the patient may need urgent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). The bleeding risk does not outweigh the benefit in these circumstances, and vice versa if patients are without coronary artery disease (CAD) (Prabhakaran & Whinney, 2019).

 

Theresa, the rebound effect that Shawn is referring to explains that the abrupt cessation of drugs like aspirin can lead to an increased risk of ischemic events such has MIs and strokes in patients with a history of CAD due to the increased platelet production and aggregation in the body (Ferrandis et al., 2009). Most cardiac patients with coronary stents are on both Aspirin and Plavix. We can attempt to avoid the rebound effect by discontinuing Clopidegrel at least 5 days before surgery and use a low-dose aspirin preoperatively to avoid risk of ischemic events (Ferrandis et al., 2009).

Here's an algorithm suggested by the Prabhakaran & Whinney (2019) in the Cleveland Clinic Journal of Medicine that outlines the use of antiplatelet therapy depending on the situation:

References:

Ferrandis, R., Llau, J., & Mugarra, A. (2009). Perioperative Management of Antiplatelet-Drugs in Cardiac Surgery. Current Cardiology Reviews, 5(2), 125–132. https://doi.org/10.2174/157340309788166688.

Prabhakaran, A., & Whinney, C. (2019). Should we stop aspirin before noncardiac surgery? Cleveland Clinic Journal of Medicine, 86(8), 518–521. https://doi.org/10.3949/ccjm.86a.18075.

Responses.Author: Gregori Kuran
Responses.Content: Thank you Shawn for sharing this overview on drugs to continue versus discontinue preoperatively. To add to your insightful information that was covered I’d like to further add that anti-epileptic are another type of drug that needs careful consideration. Patients risks or seizures during the perioperative period is dependant their baseline control of their epilepsy, other factors such as anesthesia, metabolic derangement, drug and alcohol withdrawal and intracranial surgery are influential factors.(1) It is important that patients continue these anti-epileptic drugs preoperatively, as well as also ensuring that they promptly resumed during the post-operative period.(1) It is also important to be aware of the anesthetic agents used during surgery as they can have potential interactions with these anti-epileptic drugs.(2) As the presentation of seizures can change over time and become less clinically evident, the use of EEG monitoring intra-operatively is an important tool that can be utilized.(2) 1. Dhallu MS, Baiomi A, Biyyam M, Chilimuri S. Perioperative Management of Neurological Conditions. Health Serv Insights [Internet]. 2017 Jun 12 [cited 2024 Oct 9];10:1178632917711942. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5470849/ 2. Perks A, Cheema S, Mohanraj R. Anaesthesia and epilepsy. British Journal of Anaesthesia [Internet]. 2012 Apr 1 [cited 2024 Oct 9];108(4):562–71. Available from: https://www.bjanaesthesia.org.uk/article/S0007-0912(17)32260-2/fulltext

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Thank everyone for sharing the different drugs that should be continued or discontinued preoperatively.   Regarding preoperative management, I want to add that we need to be very clear with our instructions to our patients.  Patients sometimes get confused that fasting would include holding their medications.  Because of abruptly stopping their medications, I have had patients with extreme tachycardia or a systolic pressure of 190 mmHg coming in for an elective procedure that eventually got canceled. 
On the other extreme, I have patients who thought that NPO only applies to food that needs chewing.  So, I have a couple of patients coming in for cataract removals under procedural sedation who had a big bowl of creamy soup or congee on the day of surgery. Ultimately, they stayed in the preoperative holding area for an extra couple of hours before we could perform the procedures. For drugs that should be discontinued, I think drugs that increase the chance of bleeding are one of the many types that pose risks during surgery.  This is especially important for patients going for regional anesthesia, such as a spinal or epidural block, where a normal international normalized ratio (INR) level is needed.  They should be discontinued preoperatively, and some drugs may need to be discontinued up to days before surgery.  Patients who need to continue their anticoagulant therapy may use Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) to bridge the gap during the discontinuation period.  LMWH has a short half-life and does not require it to be discontinued too far in advance. As suggested by Shawn, we also need to consider the over-the-counter herbal and vitamin supplements. They can pose risks to increased bleeding, cardiovascular instability, altered fluid and electrolyte status, altered drug metabolism, and synergism with sedative drugs. For example, St. John’s wort, used to relieve depression and anxiety, can interfere with anesthetic agents and prolong their effects. Similarly, Valerian used as a sleep aid or to relieve anxiety, can also prolong the sedative effects of anesthetic agents. We usually ask patients to discontinue their herbal supplements 2 weeks before surgery, because most of them are not actually FDA-approved, and we cannot confirm the exact ingredients. We also need to be mindful that abrupt discontinuation of some herbal products, when used for long-term therapy, can cause withdrawal symptoms.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Hi Minna,
Adding on to the preoperative management for patients with diabetes, most Type II diabetics are prescribed oral hypoglycemics, such as Metformin and Glyburide, instead of insulin. We usually ask our patients to discontinue their oral hypoglycemics on the morning of surgery, since they will be NPO for the surgery with an anticipated lower-than-normal blood sugar level. I absolutely agree with you that the key is to check the blood sugar level right before surgery because there are many causes, such as stress, that could increase blood sugar despite being NPO.

Responses.Author: Shawn Page
Responses.Content:
Hi Kurt,
I work in a cardiac OR, so it is not uncommon for us to have emergent transfers from tertiary hospital, or from a hospital with a "cath lab go wrong" situation and they are filled with anticoagulants.  So, we don't have the luxury of an emergent, elective case where a pt may stop plavix a few days before.  So we will give a TXA bolus at the start of a case, and run it throughout the case.  And then at the end we are pushing platletes, factor 7, RiaSTAP, or a Prothrombin complex concentrate, and a few units of RBC to try and get any clots to form.  Then when they start clotting, we drop them off to your unit and head home and leave the rest for you an anesthesia!

Responses.Author: Kurt Protacio
Responses.Content:
Hey Shawn,
Thanks for your reply! I totally agree with what you explained about the emergent cases where the physicians need to operate as time is not on your side. Had to look up what RiaSTAP was (learned something new!) but sounds like the type of surgeries you're a part of are pretty high risk. Thanks for sharing!

Question: Question 19: Which emergency drugs would you draw up for each anesthetic case?

Responses.Author: Ryan Smith
Responses.Content:
While this question is broad given the incredibly variable types of OR cases across demographics, geographical location, and complexity of surgery; there are some emergency drugs that one could consider essential to most crises that can arise. It is common practice in most all Ontario hospitals to have essential ACLS drugs available in sealed crash cart pharmacy pre-made trays. Thus the following is specific more to the operating theatre and the emergency drugs most anesthetic teams will commonly prepare at the start of the day, or per case. _**Phenylephrine**_
  • Favoured for hypotension _**without** bradycaria._
  • α-1 adrenergic receptor agonist with minimal β-adrenergic activity.
  • Raises mean arterial pressure (MAP) via vasoconstriction of veins and arteries raising systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
  • Rapid onset of 1-3 minutes, with short duration of action 5-20 minutes.1
  • Favoured in peri-partum anesthesia as it has been shown to reduce risk of fetal acidosis.2
  • Typical adult dose: 50-100mcg IV
_**Ephedrine**_
  • Favoured for hypotension _**with**__ bradycardia._
  • Amine which acts as both a direct and indirect sympathomimetic.
  • Binds directly to α and β adrenergic receptors.
  • Indirectly, ephedrine inhibits neuronal norepinephrine (NE) reuptake, leading to longer NE binding at postsynaptic α and β adrenergic receptors.3
  • Onset: 3-5 minutes, short duration of 10-15 minutes.
  • Typical adult dose: 5-10mg IV
_**Atropine**_
  • For symptomatic bradycardia.
  • Potent antimuscarinic agent which competitively binds postganglionic acetylcholine receptors, allowing sympathetic tone to predominate.4
  • Increases heart rate and cardiac output.
  • Rapid onset of 2-4 minutes with a duration of 2-6 hours.
  • Typical adult dose: 0.5-1.0mg/kg IV
_**Glycopyrrolate**_
  • Favoured for bradycardia during induction, intubation and vagal reflex associated arrhythmias. Direct suppression of salivary gland neuronal tone, which can be helpful pre and post operatively.
  • Synthetically created quaternary amine anticholinergic (muscarinic receptor antagonist).5
  • Rapid onset of 1-2 minutes with a duration of 2-4 hours.
  • Typical adult dose: 0.2-0.4mg IV

_**Succinylcholine**_

  • Favoured for induction in rapid sequence, and laryngospasm due to its extremely rapid onset
  • Short-acting depolarizing neuromuscular blockade via adhesion to post-synaptic cholinergic receptors of the motor neuronal junction.6
  • Very rapid onset 45-60 seconds with a duration of 6-12minutes.
  • Typical adult dose: 0.6-1mg/kg.
Although not routinely prepared in the morning before cases, anesthesia providers should be keenly aware of the location of a malignant hyperthermia (MH) toolbox/cart/kit. The hallmark medication for an MH crises is Dantrolene. Dantrolene functions by blocking postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors in skeletal muscle to reduce excitation-contraction of muscle fibres.7 Dosing of Dantrolene is 2.5mg/kg initially IV, if symptoms persist repeat administrations of 1-2.5mg/kg can be given up to a maximum of 10mg/kg. Careful hemodynamic and temperature monitoring should be employed. References 1. Richards E, Lopez MJ, Maani CV. Phenylephrine [Internet]. Treasure Island: StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Oct [cited 2024 Oct 3]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534801/ 2. Dusitkasem S, Herndon BH, Somjit M, Stahl DL, Bitticker E, Coffman JC. Comparison of Phenylephrine and Ephedrine in Treatment of Spinal-Induced Hypotension in High-Risk Pregnancies. Front Med (Lausanne). 2017 Apr: 4. 3. Statler AK, Maani CV, Kohli A. Ephedrine [Internet]. Treasure Island: StatPearls Publishing; 2023 May [cited 2024 Oct 3]. Available from: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31613441/ 4. McLendon K, Preuss CV. Atropine [Internet] Treasure Island: StatPearls Publishing; 2023 June [cited 2024 Oct 4]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470551/ 5. Gallanosa A, Stevens JB, Quick J. Glycopyrrolate [Internet]. Treasuree Island: StatPearls Publishing; 2023 June [cited 2024 Oct 4]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK526035/ 6. Hager HH, Burns B. Succinylcholine [Internet]. Treasure Island: StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Feb [cited 2024 Oct 3]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499984/ 7. Ratto D, Joyner RW. Dantrolene [Internet]. Treasure Island; StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Apr [cited 2024 Oct 4]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK535398/

Responses.Author: Meera Sathananthan
Responses.Content: Thanks for the breakdown, Ryan! You’ve done a great job covering the key emergency medications we should have ready to go in the OR. I particularly appreciate how you highlighted the roles of phenylephrine and ephedrine in managing hypotension—definitely essential tools. One other drug I’d suggest keeping drawn up is propofol. While it’s primarily used for induction and maintenance, it’s incredibly helpful in emergencies when quick re-sedation is needed. For example, if a patient doesn’t wake up as expected after a case or if laryngospasm occurs, propofol’s fast onset (typically within a minute) allows for rapid sedation and regaining control of the airway (1). Its short duration and quick action make it a great option to have on hand when things don’t go as planned. It also has the added benefit of acting as an antiemetic at certain doses, which may help with extubating patients after a case (1). I also completely agree with your point about being familiar with the MH cart. While dantrolene is crucial, close monitoring of hemodynamics and temperature is just as important in managing an MH crisis. Having propofol ready in these situations can help with managing sedation while other interventions are being carried out. Looking forward to hearing if other people have seen other things drawn up in case of emergencies! **References:** 1. Folino TB, Muco E, Safadi AO, Parks LJ. Propofol. In: StatPearls [Internet]. StatPearls Publishing; 2023 [cited 2024 Oct 6]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430884/

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Gregori Kuran
Responses.Content: Thank you Ryan for covering some of the emergency drugs you would draw for you anesthetic case, this will be a valuable resource when reviewing throughout the term. Phoebe I also agree with you that the emergency drugs you prepare are very much dependant on the patient history and the type of surgery being performed. I’d like to share some personal experience with a relatively new procedure that we have been seeing more at SickKids in our neuro interventional rooms. We have been treating more and more retinoblastoma patients with intraarterial chemotherapy (IAC). As our department started getting exposed to more and more of these cases we started encountering very severe cardiorespiratory event with these patient upon the injection of the chemotherapy drug, and usually this was seen after the first treatment. As these events became more frequent the anesthesia group initiated a standard setup for all these patient, specifically having epinephrine + phenylephrine bags prepared and ready as setting a standard workflow of how they would manage these patient during these events. There have been multiple studies that have shown that these sudden and severe cardiopulmonary events during IAC treatment are likely to the trigemino-cardiac reflex (TCR), are likely to occur once the patient has become sensitized to the chemo after the first treatment.1 1.Mulin M. Anesthetic Implications Of Intraarterial Chemotherapy For Retinoblastoma: A Literature Review [Internet]; England: University of England; 2020 [cited 2024 Oct 9] https://dune.une.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1034&context=na_capstones#:~:text=Pediatric%20anesthesia%20for%20IAC%20for,ophthalmic%20artery%20under%20fluoroscopic%20visualization.

Responses.Author: Shawn Page
Responses.Content: Good call Ryan with the ACLS drugs handy.  I find the drug trays in our main OR's (non cardiac) have all the essentials from ACLS, to bronchodilators, to steroids.  One thing I always make sure is drawn up is phenylephrine, as you mentioned.  Our main OR drug trays come with pre filled syringes of 50 mg/ml, but some anesthetists like a stronger dose of 80 or 100mg/ml.  The pre filled syringes are easily identifiable, but I always ask what the concentration is when an  has anethestist has made their own.  Another drug I have drawn up is Nitro for hypertension.  We watch the pressures in all surgeries, but in cardiac, depending on where they are in attaching the conduits, we need different pressures. And some surgeons want a pressure dropped faster, than increasing sevo, or adjusting the bed into reverse Trendelenburg, or weaning a levo drip can deliver.  I also like nitro as it doesn't change the pts anesthesia like giving a dose of propofol. Also, depending on if there is a roc infusion or not, I also like having roc drawn up in case the paralytic stops working and the pt starts to move intraop.  I have seen this only a handful of times during cardiac surgery, and it's always scary as heck because of the fine nature of suturing the anastomosis, so not having to turn around, find the vial, draw it up and then push - having it already drawn up saves a few seconds, and we can just push right away. Another drug in cardiac OR i have drawn up is a larger, By-pass dose of heparin, when we are doing an "off pump" case.  I like to have 30 000 units drawn, my organizations max one time dose, so that if the pt crashes intraop and we are doing a "crash onto pump" the room gets suddenly chaotic, and if that heparin is already drawn, all we have to do is push it, and then move onto the next task.  This will have me push it, while anesthesia is pushing pre-arrest drugs, and we work in tandem to get the pt ready for a crash pump.

Question: Question 2: Discuss the differences between agonists, antagonists, and agonist-antagonists. Provide an example for each.

Responses.Author: Laryssa Hartmann
Responses.Content:
An agonist is a chemical or drug that has an affinity for a specific receptor and activates it, thereby producing a biological response (demonstrating efficacy) (Gardenhire, 2020, p. 91). There are full agonist and partial agonist. Full agonist are drugs that achieve maximal effect. Partial agonist is those that have a less than maximal effect. To fully understand the difference between Full agonist and partial agonist, one must understand how efficacy is affected. “Efficacy is a measure of drug effectiveness once it occupies a receptor” (Kim et al., 2023., p. 42). Similar drugs that work through the same receptor may have varying degrees of effectiveness despite occupying the same receptor site (Kim et al., 2023., p. 42-45). As shown in Figure 1 (Gardenhire, 2020, p. 91) a full agonist and partial agonist may occupy the same receptor site, however, full agonist has an overall higher maximal response than a partial agonist.

 

Figure 1: Dose response curve for full and partial agonists. Adapted from Rau’s respiratory care pharmacology (Gardenhire, 2020, p. 91)

 

An example of a partial agonist is buprenorphine. Buprenorphine is a synthetic opioid used to treat pain and opioid disorder (Kumar et al., 2024). Buprenorphine is a partial agonist that acts on the opioid MU (μ) receptor.  Unlike a full agonist, buprenorphine exerts a milder effect. Buprenorphine is a potent analgesic that acts on the central nervous system and has unique properties due to its partial agonism at the mu receptor (Kumar et al., 2024). Partial agonist can sometimes act as an antagonist when given in high concentrations and in conjunction with a full agonist. For instance, buprenorphine will block morphine (full agonist) and cause competitive inhibition (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022., p. 795-796).

Epinephrine is an example of a full agonist. Epinephrine is a full alpha and beta agonist. This drug produces the same intensity or maximal effect as endogenous epinephrine. It effects both the alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors using a G protein linked second messenger system. Epinephrine increases vascular smooth muscle contraction, increases heart rate and myocardial contractility (Dalal & Grujic, 2024).  

In comparison to an agonist, an antagonist is a chemical or drug that also has an affinity to a corresponding receptor, however, does not initiate a response (demonstrates zero efficacy). The antagonist blocks the receptor site, in turn preventing endogenous chemicals from occupying and activating the receptor site (Gardenhire, 2020, p. 91).

 

Antagonist can be further divided into competitive and noncompetitive. Competitive antagonists compete with the agonist at the receptor site and prevent it from binding (Flood & Shafer, 2022., p.139). Increasing amounts of the agonist would be needed to outcompete the binding site on the receptor. For instance, Naloxone is a competitive antagonist. Naloxone has a binding affinity to Mu (μ) opioid receptors, it blocks other opioids like morphine and reverses the effects of an opioid overdose (Saari et al., 2024).

There is also noncompetitive antagonist where after the antagonist drug is administered, it binds to a different site on the receptor altering the receptors conformation where an agonist will no longer be able to bind. Even if you increase the amount of agonist available, it will still not be able to bind to the receptor site (Flood & Shafer, 2022., p.139). Ketamine would be an example of a noncompetitive antagonist. Ketamine noncompetitively binds to the NMDA receptors changing the way the receptor functions and inhibits glutaminergic transmission (Rathmell & Dahan, 2022., pp. 628-630).

 References:

Cummings III, K. C., & Naguib, M. A. (2022). In K. Donnellan & A. Fischer (Eds). Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anesthetic practice (6th ed., 795-796. 722-845). Wolters Kluwer. https://lccn.loc.gov/2020052843

Dalal, R., & Grujic, D. (2024). Epinephrine. In National Library of Medicine. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482160/

Flood, P. F., & Shafer, S. L. (2022). In K. Donnellan & A. Fischer (Eds). Basic Principles of Pharmacology. (6th ed., 139. 137-237). Wolters Kluwer. https://lccn.loc.gov/2020052843

Gardenhire, D. S. (2020). Principles of Drug Action. In D. S. Gardenhire (Ed). Rau’s respiratory care pharmacology (10th ed., 91. 49-95). Elsevier.

Kim, T. K., Obara, S., & Johnson, K. B. (2023). Basic Pharmacologic Principles. In M. C. Pardo Jr. (Ed). Miller's basics of anesthesia (8th ed.,42-45.31-49). Elsevier

Kumar, R., Viswanath, O., & Saadabadi, A. (2024). Buprenorphine. In National Library of Medicine. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459126/

Rathmell, J. P., & Dahan, A. (2022). In K. Donnellan & A. Fischer (Eds). Intravenous Sedatives and Hypnotics. (6th ed., 628-630. 544-690). Wolters Kluwer. https://lccn.loc.gov/2020052843

Saari, T. L., Strang, J., & Dale, O. (2024). Clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of naloxone. In National Library of Medicine. https://pubmed-ncbi-nlm-nih-gov.michener.idm.oclc.org/38485851/

Responses.Author: Ryan Christopher Floro
Responses.Content:
Hi Laryssa,

 

I found your discussion of agonists and antagonists interesting especially noting how partial agonists can become antagonists in some cases. It had me wondering – would it also be possible for antagonists to function as agonists on some cases? Whether in drug combinations like buprenorphine and morphine or in their own right?

 

What I came across while searching were inverse agonists. Instead of enhancing or blocking a given receptor, their binding to the receptor will produce a negative or opposite effect (Berg & Clarke, 2018). As an example, olmesartan binds to the angiotensin 2 type 1 receptor, leading to lower blood pressure (Canadian Society of Pharmacology and Therapeutics, n.d.). Such receptors have a basal level of activity even without an agonist or ligand present, which is then suppressed by the inverse agonist (Berg & Clarke, 2018). In contrast, a neutral antagonist might not change the receptor’s baseline activity but rather prevent an agonist or ligand from enhancing the activity (Berg & Clarke, 2018).

 

 

References

 

Berg, K. A., Clarke, W. P. (2018). Making sense of pharmacology: Inverse agonism and functional selectivity. International Journal of Neuropsychopharmacology, 21(10), 962-977. https://doi.org/10.1093/ijnp/pyy071

 

Canadian Society of Pharmacology and Therapeutics. (n.d.). Glossary of pharmacology: Inverse agonist. https://pharmacologycanada.org/Inverse-Agonist

Responses.Author: Laryssa Hartmann
Responses.Content:
Hey Ryan!

Thanks for sharing your thoughts on agonists and antagonist! You are right that partial agonists can act as antagonist in certain contexts, especially when they bind to receptors that are already activated by a full agonist (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022., p. 795-796). As for inverse agonists, its very interesting to consider how they work and what they do at the receptor level. Like you mentioned, inverse agonists reduce the basal activity of receptors that have some intrinsic activity, they inhibit spontaneous receptor signaling that occurs in the absence of an agonist (Klein et al., 1996). This can lead to effects that might resemble agonists activity.

 

In terms of drug combinations, like buprenorphine and morphine. Buprenophrine is a long-acting analgesic designed for pain relief and opioid use disorder (Poliwoda et al., 2022). It has a unique profile that contributes to its effectiveness in managing both pain and opioid dependence.

Buprenorphine acts as a partial agonist at opioid MU (μ) receptors. It can exhibit antagonist properties, when morphine (a full agonist) is also administered alongside buprenorphine (Kumar et al., 2024). Buprenorphine can exhibit antagonist properties by partially blocking the effects of morphine.

 

I really appreciate your explanation of neutral antagonists. From my understanding they prevent agonists from enhancing the receptors action, but they do not suppress any natural signaling that occurs when no agonists are present (Klein et al., 1996).

To simply compare an inverse agonist and neutral antagonist. An inverse agonist actively decreases activity whereas a neutral antagonist does not. Understanding these receptor interactions is important for making an effective plan for therapy.  Thank you for contributing!

 

 

References :

Klein, E. S., Pino, M. E., Johnson, A. T., Davies, P. J., Ngpal, S., Thacher, S. M., Krasinski, G., & Chandraratna, R. A. (1996, September). Identification and functional separation of retinoic acid receptor neutral antagonists and inverse agonists. In Science Direct. Buprenorphine and its formulations: A comprehensive review. In National Library of Medicine. Retrieved October 2, 2024, from https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9392838/

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Thanks, Laryssa and Ryan, for a great review on how drugs can interact with receptors as agonists, partial agonists, antagonists, and inverse agonists.
I want to add the concept of allosteric modulation. As we have discussed, agonist drugs typically bind to the same place on the receptor as the substance that naturally activates the receptor, or the endogenous agonist. These agonist drugs can further be divided into 3 categories. Full agonists generate a maximal response at a receptor. Partial agonists can only generate a fraction of the possible response at a receptor. Inverse agonists produce effects that are opposite to those of an agonist.
Some drugs may bind to a receptor at a different site from where an agonist binds, and influence the function of the receptor. These drugs are often called allosteric modulators. Positive allosteric modulators increase the likelihood of an agonist binding to a receptor and enhance the effects an agonist has when it does bind. An example is benzodiazepines. These drugs bind to an allosteric site of the GABA-A receptor and enhance the inhibitory effects of GABA. On the other hand, negative allosteric modulators decrease the affinity or efficacy of the agonist. For example, Flumazenil competitively antagonizes the allosteric sites where benzodiazepine binds and reverses the effects of benzodiazepines. It is important to note that allosteric modulators only function in the presence of the bound endogenous agonist.
Lastly, non-competitive antagonists do not compete with the agonist for the same binding site. As Laryssa mentioned, they bind to a different site on the receptor, and cause a change in the receptor activity so that even a high concentration of agonist cannot completely overcome the antagonism. An example is Ketamine, a non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor, which prevents the receptor from being activated by glutamate.

Question: Question 20: Discuss the role and effectiveness of anti-emetic agents in preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting. What factors should be considered when choosing an anti-emetic regimen?

Responses.Author: Adrian Harris
Responses.Content:
• Post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) can impact on patients from the emergence phase of the procedure up to 48-72 hrs after, potentially affecting a patient’s quality of recovery, length of stay, fluid and electrolyte imbalance, an airway free from aspirate, and wound healing among other challenges
  • To understand which antiemetics should be offered to prevent PONV, we should first briefly understand the physiological processes and the risk factors behind both nausea and vomiting, as one process can occur without the other (1)
  • Stimulus from the vestibular (inner ear), visceral (internal organs), the cerebral cortex and limbic system (cognitive and emotional centres) in the central nervous system (CNS), and vagal stimulus in the peripheral and autonomic nervous system (PNS/ANS) can all lead to the sensation of nausea, although its mechanism is still truly not well-understood (2)
  • The brain’s chemoreceptor trigger zone (CRTZ), which is outside of the blood-brain barrier (BBB), is impacted by either activation or inhibition of neurotransmitters such as dopamine, histamine, acetylcholine, substance P and serotonin; the CRTZ relays signals to the vomiting centre where cranial nerves then result in a motor process to induce vomiting (1)
  • Determining the risk of PONV can be utilized via the Apfel Score, where one point is given for each of the risk factors, with each factor adding about 20% to likelihood of PONV (3); similarly, one point given for each risk factor for pediatric patients (4), illustrated in figure 2 below

 

Figure 1. Simplified Apfel score for adults (5)

 

 

PONV Risk Factors in Children

 

Figure 2. Simplified PONV risk score for children (6)

 

  • Furthermore, increased length of surgery, surgical procedures such as cholecystectomy, laparoscopy and gynecologic surgery and patients receiving inhalational anesthesia are all associated with increased occurrence of PONV; with all these potentially compounding risks, the goal in managing PONV should be in its prevention (7)
  • Recent evidence-based consensus on PONV management recommended that:
    • Prophylactically preventing PONV should be forefront
    • Patients with 1-2 risk factors should receive 2 antiemetic agents
    • Patients with > 2 risk factors should receive 3-4 antiemetic agents
    • If the appropriate number of antiemetics were received at the appropriate time but PONV has still occurred, then offering another dose of antiemetics of the same class(es) will not be effective within 6 hours of the original dose; the provider should offer a different antiemetic class to assist with persistent symptoms (7)
  • Antiemetic offerings for PONV should be tailored to the patient’s individual needs (7)

 

Antiemetic

Mechanism of Action

Dosage

Side Effects/Relevant Information

5-HT3 antagonists

(ondansetron/

Zofran)

-selectively binds to 5-HT3 receptors are found in the brain around the CRTZ and the gastrointestinal

(GI) tract (1)

 

Adult: 4-8 mg IV (over 2-5 min) immediately before induction

Peds: 0.05-0.10 mg/kg IV pre- or intra-op (1)

- free of neurologic side effects (1)

-risk of QTc prolongation – avoid in patients with long QT syndrome, bradyarrhythmias, or patients who are receiving meds that prolong QT (6)

Histamine-receptor antagonists

(dimenhydrinate/

Gravol)

-binds to histamine-receptor subtype H1 receptors in the vomiting centre and blocks muscarinic receptors in the vestibular system (1)

Adult: 1mg/kg IV (5)

Peds (<12yrs): 0.5-1.25 mg/kg IV/IM/PR (9)

-can cause paradoxical CNS stimulation or CNS depression, drowsiness or sedation (9)

Corticosteroids

(dexamethasone)

-unclear mechanism of action (1)

Adult: 4-10 mg IV once before or after induction (10)

 

-perioperative hyperglycemia may be seen in high BMI and diabetic patients (1)

Dopamine-receptor antagonists

(metoclopramide/

Maxeran/Reglan)

-decreases signal sensitivity from GI tract to CRTZ

-accelerates gastric emptying and increases resting tone of lower esophageal sphincter  

Adult: 10 mg IV administered near the end of the case (11)

 

-especially useful in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (11)

-avoid use in patients with Parkinson disease or with dopamine-inhibition movement disorders

-may cause sensations of restlessness; use with caution in patients with restless leg syndrome (1)

-avoid in any patients with potential GI obstructions (7)

Other pharmacologic options with antiemetic properties:

Scopolamine – transdermal patch applied behind the ear (1)

Benzodiazepines – midazolam: shown in meta-analysis from 2016 to have some antiemetic properties (12)

Hypnotics – propofol: use of total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) with propofol has been found to have anti-emetic effects (7)

Antihistamines – diphenhydramine: first generation H1-receptor antagonist widely-used for allergic rhino-conjunctivitis (13)

 

Non-pharmacologic therapy:

Isopropyl alcohol pads – several studies, including one published by the Journal of the College of Family Physicians of Canada suggest holding pads 1-2 cm below the nares; multiple pads can be used for relief of nausea within about 10-15 min (14); anecdotal evidence from the anesthesia assistants at Unity Health Toronto-St Michael’s strongly support this!
