Responses.Author: Deena Kurilsky
Responses.Content:
Hi Adrian! Thank you for your overview on post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV). I appreciate the detailed breakdown of the various antiemetic options. The inclusion of the Apfel score and its application to both adult and pediatric populations is particularly valuable. It provides a clear framework for assessing risk and guiding PONV treatment. The diagrams included are very helpful.

 

My question for you is how can the timing of administering antiemetics be optimized to enhance their effectiveness in preventing PONV?

 

In my experience, I have observed that during longer surgical procedures, anesthesia typically administers an antiemetic towards the end of the case, usually just before surgical closure. This was supported in an article by Cruz et al. (2008) that suggested administration of ondansetron 30 minutes prior to the end of the case proved to be more effective in prevention of PONV then given earlier on. I wonder if you have had similar experiences or if this differs with different antiemetics or length of surgeries.

 

Cruz, N. I., Portilla, P., & Vela, R. E. (2008). Timing of ondansetron administration to prevent postoperative nausea and vomiting. Puerto Rico health sciences journal, 27(1), 43–47. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18450232/

Responses.Author: Junia Isaac
Responses.Content:
Hi Adrian and Deena! Thank you both for the valuable insights on post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) management! Adrian, I appreciate your detailed breakdown of the physiology behind nausea and vomiting, as well as the Apfel score for risk assessment. The evidence-based recommendations you included on tailoring antiemetic regimens based on the number of risk factors are extremely helpful, especially the guidance on not repeating the same class of antiemetics within 6 hours. It highlights the importance of understanding the pharmacodynamics of these agents in clinical practice. 

 

Deena, your question on the timing of antiemetics brings up an excellent point about their efficacy depending on when they’re administered. I agree that timing plays a crucial role, especially during longer surgeries. I’ve also seen evidence supporting the idea that antiemetics like ondansetron are more effective when administered closer to the end of surgery (Sun et al., 1997; Cruz et al., 2008). Do you think this is mainly due to the half-life of the drugs or could it be more related to the patient’s individual metabolism or the type of anesthesia being used? Also, Adrian, based on your discussion about different neurotransmitter pathways, do you think certain antiemetics are better suited to be administered earlier or later in surgery? It would be interesting to explore if optimizing timing based on these factors could further improve PONV prevention, especially in high-risk patients. Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!

 

Sun, R., Klein, K. W., & White, P. F. (1997). The effect of timing of ondansetron administration in outpatients undergoing otolaryngologic surgery. Anesthesia and analgesia, 84(2), 331–336. https://doi-org.uhn.idm.oclc.org/10.1097/00000539-199702000-00016

 

Cruz, N. I., Portilla, P., & Vela, R. E. (2008). Timing of ondansetron administration to prevent postoperative nausea and vomiting. Puerto Rico health sciences journal, 27(1), 43–47.

Responses.Author: Janet Rozek
Reneerose Ong
Responses.Content:
Thank you, Adrian your post provides a thorough explanation of the physiological mechanisms, behind post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Your table outlining the various anti-emetic options is helpful as a quick reference with dosages, side effects and mechanism of action. 

I particularly appreciated your discussion of the Apfel score in adults and children, and how essential it is in identifying patients at high risk for PONV, allowing for pre-emptive action. As you pointed out, patients with multiple risk factors should receive more aggressive prophylactic treatment, with the guidelines suggesting 2-4 antiemetic agents depending on the severity of the risk (Gan et al., 2020). This is critical in surgical environments, as preventing PONV can lead to improved patient outcomes and satisfaction (Gan et al., 2020). Like Janet’s experience, I have also seen the anesthesiologist give dexamethasone IV shortly after induction and ondansetron IV towards the end of the procedure, before waking up the patient to mitigate any PONV.

I was surprised to learn about the use of isopropyl alcohol pads. It sounds to be an excellent non-pharmacological method, and useful in cases where medication may be less effective or contraindicated. I am amazed that the simple act of inhaling isopropyl alcohol vapor can significantly reduce nausea within minutes (Lindblad et al., 2018). Its a technique I would like to implement in my current practice when appropriate.

Responses.Author: Paula Watkis
Responses.Content: Hi Adrian, This is a thorough explanation of the topic I completely agree with your perspective points. Based on the literature I have reviewed, I completely agree with your perspective on the role of effectiveness antiemetics agents in preventing PONV and the factors to be considered when choosing those drugs.  The use of antiemetics can make a significant difference in patient recovery in reducing discomfort to preventing complications. In previous practice, in oncology, a multimodal approach was used, where ondansetron and dexamethasone would be combined due to its efficacy in high risk patients. After reading the topic, there were some new information garnered especially on ondansetron, since it is more commonly used in my current practice setting  I am aware of the risk of hyperglycemia however to add to your point, there have been concerns surrounding the use of dexamethasone in the pediatric oncology population. For those patients who undergo anesthesia for bone marrow biopsy or lumbar puncture, the mechanism of action is unclear, but it is stated that glucocorticoids can interfere with cell counts and chemotherapy management and in rare cases can cause tumor lysis syndrome. The use of the isopropyl is an old practice for many in the caribbean,, without them knowing the implications. It has been used very extensively by the older population and is used for every ailment including regular nausea and vomiting, pyrexia just to name a few things. References: Feinlab, J. Stoelting's Handbook of Pharmacology and Physiology in Anesthetic Practice. LWW

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Thanks, Adrian, for a detailed review on anti-emetics.  Nausea and vomiting are the most common post-anesthetic complications. Aside from unpleasantness for the patient and staff, postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) poses medical risks. Increased intra-abdominal pressure and forceful vomiting jeopardize abdominal suture lines or can disrupt hemostasis at the surgical site of neurosurgical, head and neck, thoracic, and intraabdominal surgeries. Elevated central venous pressure increases morbidity after ocular, tympanic, or intracranial procedures. PONV also increases the risk of aspirating gastric contents, especially if airway reflexes are impaired. Movement during PONV worsens postoperative pain and accentuates autonomic responses. Finally, PONV can delay discharge or necessitate the admission of ambulatory patients. Although routine anti-emetic prophylaxis is clearly unjustified, patients at high risk for PONV should receive special consideration. Therefore, the identification of at-risk patients is the keystone in management.  Adding onto Adrian’s risk factors, we can group them into three categories.  Patient-specific factors:
  • Female
  • Non-smoking status
  • History of PONV or motion sickness
  • History of migraines – This has been identified as a new risk factor.
Anesthetic risk factors:
  • Use of volatile anesthetics within 2 hours
  • Use of nitrous oxide
  • Use of intraoperative and postoperative opioids
Surgical risk factors:
  • Duration of surgery – Each 30-minute increase in surgical duration increases PONV risk by ~20%
  • Type of surgery – laparoscopy, ear-nose-throat, neurosurgery, breast, strabismus, laparotomy, plastic surgery
  • Significant blood loss during surgery can also contribute

Question: Question 21: What are some anesthesia considerations regarding patients taking Semaglutide (Ozempic)?

Responses.Author: Gregori Kuran
Mary Johnsy Joseph
Responses.Content:
Hi Gregori, thank you for explaining anesthesia considerations regarding patients taking

Semaglutide (Ozempic). It is interesting to know that semaglutide may cause delayed   

gastric emptying and residual gastric contents, controversies arise on preoperative

medication management, adequate preoperative fasting periods, utilization of gastric

ultrasound, and rapid sequence induction and intubation to mitigate the risks of

regurgitation and pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents during anesthesia care (Beam,

et, al., 2014).

        In my workplace, all ophthalmologists instruct the patient who undergoes cataract

surgery to hold Ozempic for one week before surgery. People with diabetes sometimes

experience abnormally high blood sugar levels, which can cause blood vessels in the eye to

leak. This is a leading cause of vision loss.  There is a potential risk of the development of

non-arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) (Hazanchuk, 2024).  Semaglutide helps

people lose weight and control their blood sugar by releasing the hormone called GLP-1,

also prompts the body to create more insulin, which reduces blood sugar. When the body

experiences a change in sugar level, it can affect the shape of the eye’s lens causes

diabetic retinopathy. This change is what causes blurry vision, a side effect of semaglutide

(Hazanchuk, 2024).

         American society of anesthesiologists (2023) explained that the Day or week prior to the procedure:

  • Hold GLP-1 agonists on the day of the procedure/surgery for patients who take the medication daily.
  • Hold GLP-1 agonists a week prior to the procedure/surgery for patients who take the medication weekly.
  • Consider consulting with an endocrinologist for guidance in patients who are taking GLP-1 agonists for diabetes management to help control their condition and prevent hyperglycemia (high blood sugar).

 

        

 

References

 

 

Hazanchuk, V. (2024). Can Ozempic Affect Eye Health? Here’s What Ophthalmologists

               Want You to Know. In American academy of ophthalmology. EyeSmart Publications.

               https://www.aao.org/eye-health/news/can-ozempic-affect-eye-health-here-s-what-   ophthalm

Pai, S., Smith, A. M., Beam, W. B., & Harbell, W. M. (2014). Perioperative Considerations for

                Patients on Semaglutide. In SpringerNature. SpringerNature Publications.

                https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40140-024-00611-6 14, 152-160

American Society of Anesthesiologists (2023). Patients Taking Popular Medications for    

               Diabetes and Weight Loss Should Stop Before Elective Surgery, ASA Suggests, In ASA,

               ASA Publications. https://www.asahq.org/research-and-publications

Responses.Author: Janelyne Mandegarian
Responses.Content:
Hello Gregory and Mary,

 

Gregory thank you for clarifying the considerations of semaglutides and the increased risk for aspiration. Also, thank you Mary for tying this practice into your workplace. Very informative from both of you. 

I wanted to touch more on the point of care ultrasound for patients who are on semaglutides. The American Society of Anesthesiologist (ASA) recommends doing one at bedside, but it is to the discretion of the anesthesiologists. Ultrasounds are non-invasive, does not cause increased risk of radiation prior to surgery and simple to complete. It mitigates the risks of aspiration or to the least allows for health care providers to have the best plan of action and preparedness if risks is involved. If gastric contents are visualized, then risk must be evaluated on whether to continue with the procedure to lessens the level of risk either by delaying surgery, rescheduling date or proceeding with caution and discuss with the patient the risk or regurgitation and aspiration. If empty proceed as normal. If ultrasound is inconclusive or not possible, the presumptive action is they have “full stomach” and proper precautions to be taken.

Interestingly, I found the parameters for Canadian Journal of anesthesiology (CJA) recommendation of 3 weeks to be lengthy but again the half life of semaglutides is 7 days and I want to note that my organizations uses the ASA recommendation as you both stipulated above (1 week). It has been discussed there may be increased risk for patients undergoing conscious sedation or deep sedation as there is no endotracheal tube (ETT) protecting the airway (Fezza, 2023). There is varying level of the severity for aspiration like hypoxia, airway obstruction, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), complete respiratory failure or death. Gastric contents can change the level of severity with PH, volume aspirated and sterility of the contents (Nason, 2015). If doing a point of care ultrasound mitigates the unnecessary pulmonary aspiration risk which in turns alleviates the potential for rapid intubation and ICU admission, should it not be done pre-operatively and put into protocol? 

 

References

The American Society of Anesthesiologists. (2023). Patients Taking Popular Medications for Diabetes and Weight Loss Should Stop Before Elective Surgery, ASA Suggests https://www.asahq.org/about-asa/newsroom/news-releases/2023/06/patients-taking-popular-medications-for-diabetes-and-weight-loss-should-stop-before-elective-surgery

Fezza, R., Rains, B., Fezza, T., & Fezza, J. P. (2023). Emerging Anesthesia Risks with Semaglutide. Plastic and reconstructive surgery. Global open, 11(11), e5427. https://doi.org/10.1097/GOX.0000000000005427

Nason K. S. (2015). Acute Intraoperative Pulmonary Aspiration. Thoracic surgery clinics, 25(3), 301–307. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.thorsurg.2015.04.011

Responses.Author: Meera Sathananthan
Responses.Content:
Hello Gregori, Mary, and Janelyne, Thank you all for your discussion on the anesthesia management of patients taking semaglutide (Ozempic). It's especially important with more people using it off-label nowadays for diet regimens.  Off-label use of semaglutide for weight loss carries potential risks, such as gastrointestinal side effects, dehydration, and possible electrolyte imbalances, which can also complicate anesthesia management. These risks are highlighted in clinical literature that associates GLP-1 receptor agonists with delayed gastric emptying and gastrointestinal disturbances (1). As a respiratory therapist, I’d like to expand a bit more on the airway management considerations and monitoring strategies in these high-risk patients, particularly with the increased risk of aspiration.  Patients on semaglutide are at increased risk of having delayed gastric emptying, which can lead to residual gastric contents and subsequently increases the risk of regurgitation and aspiration during anesthesia. For these patients, I would emphasize the importance of a rapid sequence induction (RSI) approach, as Gregori mentioned, with cricoid pressure as part of standard airway management (1, 2). Cricoid pressure involves applying pressure to the cricoid cartilage to occlude the esophagus, thereby reducing the risk of gastric content regurgitation during induction (Figure 1.0). This provides an extra layer of safety when a full stomach is assumed.

_Figure 1: The application of cricoid pressure during intubation. Not only does this help provide a better view of the airway but helps in occluding the esophagus, acting as a barrier for potential gastric aspiration (3)._
Additionally, it's important to consider the use of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) carefully. Given the risks, it would be prudent to avoid LMAs in patients on semaglutide when possible, as they do not provide the level of airway protection as endotracheal intubation. LMAs do not create a complete seal against gastric regurgitation, which increases the risk of aspiration in high-risk patients (2). Instead, opting for endotracheal intubation would better protect the airway in the event of regurgitation, particularly during general anesthesia or deep sedation. Monitoring for signs of aspiration is crucial during the perioperative and postoperative periods. Specific monitoring techniques such as capnography, auscultation, and close observation of oxygen saturation can help in detecting early signs of aspiration. Indicators such as a sudden drop in oxygen saturation, increasing ventilation pressures, wheezing, or respiratory distress should prompt rapid intervention to prevent further complications like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or even respiratory failure (2). Furthermore, the use of sedation techniques can also significantly impact risk. Procedures involving moderate or deep sedation should be approached with caution, given that the lack of a protected airway increases the risk for aspiration if gastric contents are present (1). Where possible, regional anesthesia might be considered as an alternative to general anesthesia, especially in patients with poorly controlled diabetes or those at a higher risk due to residual gastric contents. Lastly, the use of bedside gastric ultrasound as a standard practice for patients on semaglutide could aid in visualizing gastric contents, thereby allowing for a more tailored anesthesia approach. As Janelyne pointed out, if ultrasound findings suggest full gastric contents, RSI or even postponing surgery may be warranted (1). Given the non-invasive nature and utility of ultrasound, incorporating it into preoperative protocols could significantly reduce unnecessary aspiration risks. Other considerations is potentially asking patients to fast longer; some sources even suggest 36 hour long liquid diets prior to OR if patients are on Ozempic in order to reduce the risk of a full stomach (4). Thank you again for this informative thread—I hope my perspective on airway management and the use of sedation techniques adds to the discussion. It will be interesting to go back to work to see if there are any guidelines or procedures in place for patients in the OR on semaglutides. 

Sincerely,

Meera
**References**

Nason KS. Acute Intraoperative Pulmonary Aspiration. Thoracic surgery clinics. 2015;25(3):301-307. Available from: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.thorsurg.2015.04.011 3. Whitten C. Cricoid pressure requires communication & teamwork [Internet]. The Airway Jedi; 2022 Feb 22 [cited 2024 Oct 6]. Available from: https://airwayjedi.com/2022/02/22/cricoid-pressure-requires-communication-teamwork/ 4. Fujino E, Cobb KW, Schoenherr J, Gouker L, Lund E. Question: Question 22: Compare and contrast the advantages and disadvantages of different routes of administering analgesics for managing postoperative pain.

Responses.Author: Teresa Nguyen
Responses.Content:
By effectively treating post-operative pain, healthcare providers can help improve surgical outcomes and lower cost of hospitalizations (3). Every patient is different. Choosing the most appropriate form of analgesia for the patient requires considering the route of administration, dosage, limitations and contraindications (3). I have summarized the advantages and disadvantages into the following table:

 

 

Oral

Advantages:

  • Simple and non-invasive compared to other routes (3)
  • Good efficacy (similar to the IV route) (3)
  • Can be immediate release or controlled release (3)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Contraindicated in patients experiencing vomiting or delayed gastric emptying (3)
  • Risk of “dumping effect” which occurs when patients ingest oral analgesics before they gain regular gastric motility leading to accumulated doses entering the intestine at the same time leading to systemic uptake of a large amount of analgesics (3)

 

IV

Advantages:

  • Fastest route (3)
  • IV route ensures rapid onset of pain relief without the uncertainty of other medications absorbed by other routes (3)
  • PCA (Patient Controlled Analgesia) allows patients who have adequate cognitive function to gain flexibility to use their PCA pump independently (3)

 

Disadvantages:

  • More costly in terms of opioids, paracetamol or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) (3)
  • PCA pumps with a continuous infusion increases risk of nausea, vomiting and respiratory events (3)
  • Certain IV medications have less bioavailability and tolerability when compared to their oral version (e.g. paracetamol) (3)

 

IM/ subcut

Advantages:

  • Enters systemic circulation, bypassing the first-pass metabolism (1)
  • Muscles are highly vascularized (1)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Poor perfusion (e.g hypovolemia or hypothermia) can impact absorption leading to inadequate pain relief and/or late side effects when the medication distributes when perfusion improves (3)

 

Transdermal

Advantages:

  • Non-invasive and easy to apply (3)
  • When applied to the skin, analgesics are systemically absorbed (3)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Onset and offset times are slow (3)
  • Unable to titrate medications on a short-term basis (3)

 

Transmucosal

Advantages:

  • Rapidly enters the systemic circulation bypassing hepatic metabolism (first-pass metabolism) (3)
  • Routes include sublingual, buccal, intranasal and rectal (3)
  • Can be self-administered (2)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Limited if patient experiences emesis (sublingal and buccal route cannot be given) (3)
  • Drug dissolution and absorption is a challenge with patients who have dry mucosa (e.g. dry mouth condition) (2)
  • Risk of choking and aspiration in young or elderly patients (2)
  • Small surface area for absorption (2)

 

Rectal

Advantages:

  • Fairly easy to administer (3)
  • Rapid systemic drug absorption as the rectal mucosa is highly vascularized (2)
  • Not limited by emesis (2)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Varying absorption and rectal irritation amoung patients (3)
  • Contraindicated in patients who are immunocompromised, patients with pre-existing rectal lesions, and patients who recently underwent colorectal surgery (3)
  • Poor patient acceptance (2)
  • Leakage may occur (2)

 

Epidural

Advantages:

  • Higher efficacy than IV opioids (3)
  • Suggested for high-risk patients (e.g. increased risk of cardiac or pulmonary complications and prolonged ileus) during thoracic, abdominal and lower limb surgery (3)
  • Can be used adjunctively with opioids or local anesthetics to improve pain relief (3)
  • Epidural infusions have higher effectiveness and less adverse effects in comparison to PCA infusions (3)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Adverse effects include respiratory depression and severe hypotension (3)
  • There is risk of epidural hematoma or epidural abscess which may cause paraplegia (3)
  • Requires close monitoring (e.g insertion, catheter removal, dose de-escalation, and antagonist administration) (3)

 

Intrathecal

Advantages:

  • Better pain control compared to IV administration (3)

 

Disadvantages:

  • More frequent side effects than IV opioids: respiratory depression, urinary retention, nausea, vomiting and pruritis (3)

 

Peripheral Block

Advantages:

  • Recommended for specific procedures: breast surgery, cesarean section, thoracotomy, and abdominal surgeries (3)
  • Highly suggested for surgeries of the extremities (3)

 

Disadvantages:

  • Risk of local anesthetic systemic toxicity and nerve injury (however, ultrasound guidance will greatly reduce these risks) (3)
  • Other risks include bleeding and infection (3)
  • Clinicians must adhere to specific guidelines when administering peripheral blocks (3)

 

 

1. Gutierrez, J., & Munakomi, S. (2023). Intramuscular injection. StatPearls [Internet]. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556121/

 

2. Lam, J., Cheung, C., Chow, M., Harrop, E., Lapwood, S., Barclay, S., & Wong, I. (2020). Transmucosal drug administration as an alternative route in palliative and end-of-

life care during the covid-19 pandemic. Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews, 160, 234-243. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.addr.2020.10.018

 

3. Puntillo, F., Giglio, M., & Varrassi, G. (2021). The routes of administration for acute postoperative pain medication. Pain Therapy, 10(2), 909-925.

https://doi.org/10.1007/s40122-021-00286-5

Responses.Author: Mary Johnsy Joseph
Responses.Content:
Hi Teresa, thank you for sharing in detail regarding management of post operative pain. The table describes summary of each administration route, advantages and disadvantages.

       Brennan et. al., (2023) stated that it is very important to know that post operative pain management is best tailored to individual and recommends that clinicians provide patient and family-centered, individually tailored education to the patient (and/or responsible caregiver), including information on treatment options for management of postoperative pain, and document the plan and goals for postoperative pain management.

To discuss about intrathecal drug administration, orthopedic surgeons at my workplace use a triple mix solution. It is a periarticular cocktail injection consisting of 60 mL of normal saline, 30mL of 10% ropivacaine, ketorolac 30 mg, and 1 mL of adrenaline (total volume: 92 mL). This injection is administered after total joint implants placement. The organization policy recommends the use of periarticular infiltration is an effective adjunct to multimodal pain management following a joint replacement. The decision to administer triple mix solution is discussed during the briefing period of surgical procedures in which the patient and entire surgical team pauses to do the surgical safety checklist. One of the discussion sections is regarding the administration of triple mix solution. Adverse effects of ketorolac are similar to those of other NSAIDs, including gastrointestinal bleeding, nausea/vomiting, peptic ulceration, renal failure and increased bleeding due to inhibited platelet function, which may limit its effectiveness in many patients receiving total knee arthroplasty (King et. al., 2023) During perioperative checking, glomerular filter rate and creatinine clearance values are also mentioned during briefing time before surgery begins. Patients with impaired renal function receive a double mix solution which excludes ketorolac.

Responses.Author: Laryssa Hartmann
Responses.Content:
Hi Teresa,

 

I really appreciated the comparison that you made between the different routes of administrations for managing postoperative pain. The table was very helpful in understanding the advantages and disadvantages of each route of administration. I think it is important to carefully consider both the disadvantages and advantages to make the right decision for the patient. 

Mary, I also appreciated your example from your workplace. It is essential to consider a multimodal analgesia approach when managing postoperative pain. One study I found analyzed data from over 1.5 million patients who had hip or knee surgery from 2006 to 2016 (Memtsoudis et al., 2018). Patients were divided into two groups: the first group was only given only opioids as a post operative pain management, while the second group was given a combination of opioids and other methods (such as peripheral nerve blocks, acetaminophen, steroids, NSAIDs, cyclooxygenase 2 inhibitors or ketamine). This study showed that patients receiving a combination of opioids with other methods had fewer respiratory complications, fewer gastrointestinal complications and a decrease in length of hospital stay (Memtsoudis et al., 2018). This research supports the combination method that Mary uses at her workplace as a better pain management approach after surgery.  The American Society of Anesthesiologists also recommends using a multimodal approach to manage acute pain after surgery to target different pain pathways (Helander et al., 2017). Utilizing this approach enhances pain relief and overall patient comfort.

Responses.Author: Janelyne Mandegarian
Responses.Content:
Hi Theresa and Mary!

I appreciate the thorough break down of the routes of analgesia and the highlights it provides. I also agree with the multimodal approach with postoperative pain as it reduces length of hospital stay, greater outcome for pain management, it was reported that less than 50% of patient’s have proper pain control and 39% of those experience severe or extreme levels of pain (Cheung et al, 2022).

I concur pain is subjective to each individual and it can have varying factors that contribute to a patient’s tolerance, threshold and previous experiences. It is important to mention that pain management does not start intraoperatively, it can be initiated in stages through their process through different routes. I think in anesthesia it is important to have protocols and guidelines in place to accomplish early recovery after surgical procedures using evidence-based practice (Melnyk et al, 2011) like Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocol which is a multimodal perioperatively pathways. In Mary’s example of patients with total knee arthroplasty (TKA) I can also corroborate the intrathecal administration cocktail of medication but more so prior to surgery anesthesiologist order Celebrex 200mg and Tylenol 1 gram PO pre-operatively at least 1 hours before their surgery in my organization and observed to be effective as it effects different pathways and they work synergistically when combined (Cheung et al, 2022). It should also be pointed out that patients who undergo TKA can have spinals and peripheral nerve blocks which has shown patients mobilize earlier, reduce narcotic consumption, have improved pain scores and decreased hospitalization stay (Hasegawa, 2022). This last point is especially important if TKA are elective same day surgery and by experience the multimodal pain management been successful for our patients to going home the same day after TKA and can clear physiotherapy and to continue further success at home.

Responses.Author: Reneerose Ong
Responses.Content:
Thank you for providing a detailed comparison of the different routes of administration for post-operative analgesia. Your table clearly outlines the advantages and disadvantages of each route, making it easier to understand their clinical applications.

I agree that effective pain management is crucial for improving patient outcomes, as post-operative pain can significantly impact recovery time and overall patient satisfaction (Puntillo et al., 2021). A common goal for surgical centers is to provide painless hospitalization, with an emphasis on a short hospital stay, early home discharge, and quick return to normal activities (Zieliński et al., 2022). This aligns with the effective management of post-operative pain, which also helps prevent complications that could lead to re-hospitalization.

I’d like to expand on Janelyne’s point that pain management doesn’t begin intraoperatively but can start in the pre-operative phase. At my workplace it is common practice for patients to receive acetaminophen pre-operatively.  Surgeries like adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and adenotonsillotomy, which are among the most common pediatric surgeries worldwide, are associated with severe post-operative pain (Zieliński et al., 2022). Research on pain management has led to the introduction of pre-emptive analgesia, where analgesics are administered before the onset of surgical pain stimuli and continued intraoperatively (Zieliński et al., 2022). Zieliński et al. (2022) randomized control trial, demonstrated that pre-operative administration of acetaminophen significantly reduced post-operative pain in children undergoing otolaryngology procedures, highlighting the effectiveness of pre-emptive analgesia administration.

Overall, your post illustrates the complexity of post-operative pain management and the need for individualized approaches. Each method has its own benefits and limitations, and the choice of analgesia should strike a balance between maximizing pain relief and minimizing adverse effects.

medicine, 11(10), 2713. https://doi.org/10.3390/jcm11102713

Postoperative Pain Medication. _Pain and therapy, 10_(2), 909-925.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
I just want to clarify some terminology. 
Intrathecal administration is when we inject medication directly into the subarachnoid space in the spinal cord to mix with the cerebrospinal fluid. By bypassing the blood-brain barrier, intrathecal administration allows for more effective delivery of drugs to the brain and spinal cord. This route is used in spinal blocks for procedures done under regional anesthesia. Residual of the spinal block may be carried postoperatively. However, it is rarely indicated for just for acute postoperative pain management.
The periarticular injection, mentioned by Mary, is more commonly known as local infiltration analgesia. This is when the surgeon injects medication around a joint to manage pain during or after surgery. This can also be used to supplement partial or patchy regional blocks or extend the wearing-off of single-shot blocks.
The most common approach to using local anesthetics in postoperative pain management is through local infiltration shots and boluses or infusion via an epidural catheter or peripheral nerve catheter.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Shawn Page
Responses.Content:
Teresa, that was a great post.   I  found it very clear, and was a great summary and comparison without being all wordy.
Mary, I'd like to expand on what you said about pain control being tailored to each pt. I am going to be personal here.  Last week I had hip resurfacing surgery, I was planning on same day discharge. However plans changed when my BP dropped to the 80s whenever I tried to ambulate, and I am not a small guy.
My pain was 10/10 and despite multiple tabs of hydromorphone it would not change.  Then I was switched to hydromorph injections about Q30-45mins.  It took the edge off, but I was still at 9/10.  The pain team came and assessed me, and I was switched to a hydromorph PCA.  I was finally able to get the pain down to a 4 and was able to get a tiny bit of sleep that night.  I know that I was under a pain management order set.  But I appreciate that my nurse saw that it wasn't working and activated the pain team to come and see me.  I was assessed, and a new plan of care was created that ended up working for me.  So I am totally glad that you mentioned that pain control should always be pt specific.  Thank you for including this.

Question: Question 3: Compare and contrast the advantages and disadvantages of general and regional anesthesia.

Responses.Author: Kurt Protacio
Responses.Content:
When it comes to the option of using general versus regional anesthesia during a case, there are many factors to consider. General anesthesia (GA) is used to induce the entire body, maintain loss of consciousness, and after the procedure, provides the patient with no recollection of the operation. On the other hand, regional anesthesia (RA) is an option in which a portion of the body, usually lower, is anesthetized to provide a numbing and pain-free effect. Ongoing studies are being performed and reviewed to determine which route of anesthesia is best suited for different types of operations. A recent study in 2020 reviewed the use of GA and RA in Ontarians and concluded that the use of RA was linked to less days spent in hospital post operation combined with less in-hospital cardiovascular and renal complications (Roberts et al., 2020). On the other hand, RA provided to patients undergoing surgery did not significantly reduce the occurrence of postoperative delirium compared to GA and further studies are still needed to explore the best choice of anesthesia (Zhou, Zhang, Si & Shen, 2023). In addition, a combination of both GA, RA and monitored anesthesia care (MAC) techniques can be beneficial in patient comfort during a procedure. For example, patients undergoing cerebral aneurysm coiling may start by receiving MAC, but can convert to using GA by the anesthesia provider should the need arise (Pardo, 2022).  I have summarized and provided a list of other advantages and disadvantages of both GA and RA split into child and adult categories:

 

Regional Anesthesia

General Anesthesia

 

 

Advantages

Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Infant/Child

  • Minimal exposure to general anesthetics
  • Minimal disruption in feeding schedule/nursing
  • Limited duration (Spinal)
  • Limited choice of local anesthetic (avoidance of amide-group due to hepatic clearance under 1 year of age)
  • Rapid onset and reliability
  • Airway control (preoxygenation, ventilator use)
  • Inhaled anesthetic is preferred option over intravenous
  • Postoperative apnea and bradycardia in younger (preterm) infants
  • Risk of pulmonary complications (children are at higher risk of atelectasis compared to adults)
  • Possible risk of neurological development delay after surgery with prolonged use of GA

Adult

  • Safer for patients undergoing minor procedures/surgical operations (lower extremities, lower abdomen, perineum)
  • No loss of consciousness
  • Target area provides nerve block, usually peripheral nerves
  • Local muscular relaxation
  • Minimized intraoperative blood loss
  • Patient refusal
  • Limited duration
  • if inadequate block performed, the anesthesia provide has option to convert to GA
  • Risk of infection at site of injection (septic meningitis, cauda equina syndrome)
  • Temporary or permanent neuropathic pain management due to post-operative puncture
  • Higher risk of Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST)
  • Preferred for major surgeries
  • Intravenous anesthesia is preferred over inhaled
  • Provides total CNS depression & body muscle relaxation
  • Can easily extend duration of operation
  • preferred option for those with potential airway compromise and/or cardiovascular instability
  • Riskier in patients with multiple comorbidities or currently deteriorating
  • Emergent tracheostomy (awake intubation) if difficulty managing airway via mask
  • Post-operative nausea/vomiting
  • Variable hemodynamic monitoring/changes in all 3 operative phases

(Lagier et al., 2021; Pardo, 2022; Westfall & Sager, 2015; Zhou et al., 2023)

Pardo, M. C. (2022). Choice of anesthetic technique. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), _Miller's basics of anesthesia_ (8th ed., pp. 221-228). Elsevier.

Roberts, D. J., Nagpal, S. K., Kubelik, D., Brandys, T., Stelfox, H. T., Lalu, M. M., Forster, A. J., McCartney, C. J., & McIsaac, D. I. (2020). Association between neuraxial anaesthesia or general anaesthesia for lower limb revascularisation surgery in adults and clinical outcomes: population based comparative effectiveness study. BMJ, 371. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.m4104

Urman (Eds.), Essential Clinical Anesthesia Review: Keywords, Questions and Answers for the Boards (pp. 408–410). chapter, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
