Responses.Author: Laryssa Hartmann
Responses.Content:
Hi Kurt,

 

Your summary of regional and general anesthesia was really detailed and in depth. I really appreciated the table that you provided listing advantages and disadvantages of the two. I found it helpful in visualizing which technique would be better suited for patient population.

The potential for combining general, regional and monitored anesthesia care is particularly intriguing. I understand that this approach allows anesthesiologists to tailor anesthesia to specific needs of the patient which would overall enhance patient comfort.

Do you think anxiety levels play an important role in influencing the choice between general and regional anesthesia? Do you think preoperatively this could be addressed and in turn change the choice of anesthetic technique?

Responses.Author: Kelly Gram
Junia Isaac
Responses.Content:
Thank you, Kurt, for your detailed response and for highlighting the potential of combining general anesthesia (GA), regional anesthesia (RA), and monitored anesthesia care (MAC) to enhance patient comfort. I completely agree with your observation that tailoring anesthesia to the patient’s specific needs is a key strength of this approach. Thank you, Kelly, for your thoughtful contribution and for sharing your recent experiences in the OR, particularly with the administration of nerve blocks and spinal anesthetics. 

 

Laryssa, in response to your question about the influence of anxiety levels on the choice between GA and RA, I believe anxiety can indeed play a significant role. Patients who experience high levels of preoperative anxiety may be more inclined to prefer GA because of the comfort that comes from being unconscious and having no recollection of the procedure. Interestingly, studies suggest that patients with anxiety disorders tend to have an elevated perception of pain, which could further influence the decision to opt for GA over RA (Kim et al., 2020). However, addressing anxiety preoperatively through education, counselling, or anxiolytic medications can sometimes shift the preference towards RA, especially if the patient understands its advantages, such as faster recovery and reduced postoperative nausea (Yilmaz & Yanar, 2022). It’s possible that offering these interventions early could reduce the patient's anxiety enough for them to consider RA as a safer or more favourable option. Additionally, it’s important to consider how personal experiences and psychological conditioning might impact anesthetic choice. For example, patients who have had prior positive experiences with RA may be more comfortable choosing it again, while those who had complications may prefer GA. Have any of you noticed any patterns in how previous surgical experiences influence patient decisions? Another thought is how the patient's understanding of the procedure itself might affect their anxiety. Do you think a deeper understanding of the surgical process, or the role of anesthetics could help lower anxiety and shift preferences toward RA?

Finally, while anxiety plays an important role, it might be valuable to revisit the potential risks of using anxiolytic medications preoperatively, especially in patients already at risk for postoperative cognitive dysfunction. Could balancing anxiolytics and other sedatives affect the choice of RA versus GA? Additionally, I wonder if patients’ prior experiences with RA or GA affect their willingness to undergo nerve blocks while awake. Have you observed any trends in how previous experiences influence their openness to RA? Perhaps more personalized preoperative consultations and education could help make RA more approachable for those who might be hesitant.

 

References: 

 

Fitzgerald, J. E., Roberts, H., & Ferguson, H. J. (2021). Perioperative anxiety and anesthetic technique: Does it influence patient outcomes? European Journal of Anaesthesiology, 38(4), 255-262. https://doi.org/10.1097/EJA.0000000000001356

 

Kim, J. H., Lee, H. J., & Kim, D. K. (2020). Impact of preoperative anxiety on anesthetic choice. Journal of Clinical Anesthesia, 65, 109885. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclinane.2020.109885

 

Yilmaz, S., & Yanar, K. (2022). Preoperative anxiety management and its influence on anesthesia choice. Journal of Perioperative Medicine, 5(3), 143-147. https://doi.org/10.1097/JPM.0000000000000123

Responses.Author: Janelyne Mandegarian
Responses.Content:
Hello Kurt and Junia, I just want to add to your question at the end there. 

I have seen in practice (same day surgery and PACU) patients for orthopedic surgeries have repeat regional anesthesia (spinal and blocks) when it is time for their second knee replacement. They noted that pain was properly managed, early mobilization and short hospital stay proved to be enticing still. My experience with patients has been positive for the most part and with decreased anxiety during the intraoperative phase the second time. Anxiety levels can be varying and subjective like pain, one study noted that anesthesiologists tend to underestimate patients’ anxiety levels and inaccurately assess it. In a survey conducted in 2010 for anesthesiologists to report about their experiences with regional anesthetics, 39% of anesthesiologist stated the anxiety of patients can also affect their confidence perform the RA. Surprisingly 63%  felt that patients anxiety may affect the block success. They also noted that the average response for anxiety were fear of anesthesia, fear of surgery, unsuccessful block and misinformation (Jlala, Bedford & Hardman).

 Anesthesia care team (ACT) should be mindful in consultation phase to provide information of the whole process. It isn’t uncommon for pre-op nurses to give anxiolytic medication such as Ativan SL or patients are advised to take their own Ativan the morning of surgery if already taking due to their previous history. Benzos like Versed can also be given in the block room IV if needed. The other option my facility provides is deep sedation with propofol infusion. When I was discussing with the AA assisting with the spinals and blocks, he stated normally 75 mcg/kg/min or lower due to avoidance of using instrumenting the airway, however if needing to run the infusion high may necessitate securing the airway for increased risk of aspiration or obstruction. To mitigate the risk, oral airway, capnography and face mask to supplement 02 can prevent desaturation.

 

Jlala, H. A., Bedforth, N. M., & Hardman, J. G. (2010). Anesthesiologists' perception of patients' anxiety under regional anesthesia. Local and regional anesthesia, 3, 65–71. https://doi.org/10.2147/lra.s11271

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Thanks, everyone, for an excellent discussion so far! Like everything else in medicine, there is a fine balance between risks and benefits. We may run into trouble with an unanticipated difficult airway during the induction of general anesthesia, but I will definitely pick general over regional anesthesia if we run into a crisis during a surgical procedure.  As Kurt pointed out, we already have complete control of the airway under general anesthesia, so we can focus more on the hemodynamics and other aspects.  General anesthesia is also more adaptable when the length of surgery needs to be extended due to a surgical complication.   With general anesthesia, we can use inhaled anesthetics.  Inhaled anesthetics allow for an easy, titratable depth of anesthesia with the added ability to bronchodilate. We can also provide anesthesia for patients without venous access. However, inhaled anesthetics contribute to operating room pollution. Regional anesthesia requires additional skills and experience to insert regional blocks.  In addition to the different block complications, there is always a risk of block failure or inadequacy, as Kurt mentioned.  I also agree that the anxiety level can be an issue, especially hearing the surgeon hammering at the knee replacement in the background, for example. However, as many of you mentioned, regional blocks have so much potential for better postoperative pain management, leading to a quicker recovery and shortened length of hospital stay.   I also like Kurt’s idea of combining the types of anesthesia.  We often utilize this format in our thoracic and Whipple procedures as well. We would insert an epidural catheter before inducing the patient for general anesthesia. The epidural catheter is mainly for post-operative management, but it can be used intraoperatively to decrease the use of opioids. There is an interesting study by Schuster et al. (2005) on the costs of different anesthesia techniques: general anesthesia, spinal anesthesia, epidural anesthesia, and brachial plexus block. They found that spinal anesthesia was more cost-effective in short and longer cases, but epidural anesthesia did not differ too much from general anesthesia.  Brachial plexus blocks were more expensive for short cases but more cost-effective for longer cases.  Their study compared the techniques in terms of anesthesia costs and duration of surgery.  I wonder if there are any cost shifts if the results also included postoperative management. By the way, if you are interested in the anesthesia costs, there is an appendix at the end of the article comparing the cost of anesthetic drugs and supplies between regional and general anesthesia.  Whether to go with general anesthesia or regional anesthesia is a decision that all patients must make.  Obviously, certain surgical procedures dictate the type of anesthesia. For example, spinal anesthesia is the preferred choice of anesthesia for transurethral resections of the prostate (TURP) procedures because the signs and symptoms of TURP syndrome can easily be masked under general anesthesia. On the other hand, it is impossible to do a heart transplant under procedural sedation. However, if there is no absolute requirement, the decision ultimately lies with the patient.  As members of the Anesthesia Care Team, our responsibility is to know the pros and cons of the different types of anesthesia and help our patients make the best-informed decision. If you are a patient with no absolute contraindications to either general or regional anesthesia, which type of anesthesia would you pick? References

Schuster, M., Gottschalk, A., Berger, J., & Standl, T. (2005). A retrospective comparison of costs for regional and general anesthesia techniques. Anesthesia and Analgesia, 100(3): 786-794. https://doi.org/10.1213/01.ANE.0000148685.73336.70

Question: Question 4: Compare the past and present role of barbiturates in anesthesia.

Responses.Author: Dong Yue Yu
Responses.Content:
Barbiturates have historically been a widely prescribed class of drugs due to their sedative, hypnotic, or anticonvulsant effects. It is classifieds as controlled substances due to the vast prevalence of developing side effects includes physical dependence, withdraw symptoms and overdose potential

Barbiturates introduced in 1904 by the Farbwerke Fr Bayer and Co,  the first agent called diethyl-barbituric acid,  also known as barbital, malonal, or gardenal.used to treat psychiatric and neurological disorders (López-Muñoz, Ucha-Udabe, & Alamo, 2005). Barbiturates works by enhance postsynaptic gamma-aminobutyric acid, GABA-A receptor, increase chloride ion flux and, induce postsynaptic hyperpolarization and central nervous system (CNS) depression. concomitantuse with other CNS depressants, such as benzodiazepines and opioids, can cause severe respiratory depression, profound sedation, coma, and death (Suddock,Kent,Regina & Cain,2024). 

Between the 1930s and 1940s, barbiturates were the most widely used drugs as sedatives and hypnotic, The year between 1957–1963, 8469 cases of barbiturate overdose reported and 1165 deaths (Sharpless, 1970 ),  Federal Comprehensive Drug Abuse and Control Act of 1970, Barbiturates classified as Schedule II to IV substance.

Withdrawal symptoms nervousness, tremors, agitation, hypotension, delirium and grand mal seizures usually develop after 2 to 8 days abrupt cessation,  the therapeutic range for Phenobarbital is of 10 to 30 mg/L versus the fatal dose is 80 mg/L (Suddock,Kent,Regina & Cain,2024).

Benzodiazepine introduced at 1960s and replaced barbiturates rapidly, the current use of barbiturates is restricted to certain medical conditions.

Phenobarbital and primidone are still used to treat partial and tonic-clonic generalized seizures, convulsions associated with tetanus, eclampsia, cerebral hemorrhage, status epilepticus (Suddock,Kent,Regina & Cain,2024).

Thiopental still used as an intravenous anesthetic because of the fast onset and short action period make it perfect for the surgical interventions (Suddock,Kent,Regina & Cain,2024).

High dose of barbiturates have been used since the 1970s to manage acute traumatic brain injury by reducing metabolism and lowering intracranial pressure (Suddock,Kent,Regina & Cain,2024).

References

 

López-Muñoz, F., Ucha-Udabe, R., & Alamo, C. (2005). The history of barbiturates a century after their clinical introduction. Neuropsychiatric disease and treatment, 1(4), 329–343.

Suddock, J. T., Kent, K. J., Regina, A. C., & Cain, M. D. (2024). Barbiturate Toxicity. [Updated 2024 Feb 28]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Retrieved from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499875/

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam

Question: Question 5: Explore the effects of giving an opioid and a benzodiazepine together for sedative purposes.

Responses.Author: Reneerose Ong
Responses.Content:
Explore the effects of giving an opioid and a benzodiazepine together for sedative purposes

Administering an opioid and a benzodiazepine together for sedation can have significant effects on the central nervous system, requiring careful consideration of their pharmacodynamic properties. This combination is frequently used during procedural sedation and anesthesia. Commonly used benzodiazepines in the perioperative setting include diazepam, midazolam, and lorazepam (Bokoch & Su, 2023), while morphine, fentanyl, and remifentanil are the opioids most often used (Egan, 2023).

 

Synergistic Effect - Analgesia and Amnesia:

Opioids and benzodiazepines differ in their mechanism of action, but both cause depression of the central nervous system (CNS). Benzodiazepines are often used as premedication or for procedural sedation due to their amnesic (anterograde), anxiolytic and sedative properties (Bokoch & Su, 2023).  They are also used as anticonvulsants for treating seizures. Benzodiazepines work by enhancing the effect of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) at GABAA receptors (Bokoch & Su, 2023).  However, they lack hypnotic and analgesic properties (Bokoch & Su, 2023).

In contrast, opioids primarily bind to mu-opioid receptors, inhibiting pain transmission and producing analgesia and sedation or drowsiness (Egan, 2023). However, opioids alone do not consistently cause unresponsiveness or amnesia (Egan, 2023). When opioids and benzodiazepines are used together, they exhibit synergistic effects, providing better sedation, analgesia and intraoperative conditions (Yeo & Shehabi, 2023). Synergistic effects are the interaction of two or more drugs, when combined, their overall effect is greater than sum of individual effects.

Combining an opioid with benzodiazepine provides both analgesic effects (from opioid) and sedation and amnesic effects (from benzodiazepine) (Bokoch & Su, 2023; Egan, 2023). It is advantageous for procedures that require both pain relief and memory suppression.  This combination is beneficial for patients undergoing brief but painful procedures, as it helps reduce pain while minimizing the chance of remembering the procedure i.e. biopsies in pediatric patients.

 

Respiratory Depression:  

Both opioids and benzodiazepines inhibit respiratory function. Opioids primarily reduce respiratory rate through direct inhibition of mu receptors in the brainstem, while benzodiazepines decrease respiration by decreasing tidal volume (Boon et al., 2020). When administered together, the risk of respiratory depression significantly increases, leading to airway obstruction or apnea (Bokoch & Su, 2023). Both drug classes also impair upper airway patency, exacerbating the risk of significant apnea or hypoventilation (Egan, 2023).

 

Cardiovascular Effects:

Both opioids and benzodiazepines can contribute to hypotension and bradycardia (Bokoch & Su, 2023). When administered in small doses, benzodiazepines generally cause minimal changes in heart rate or blood pressure. However, large doses can lead to peripheral vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure (Bokoch & Su, 2023). Similarly, opioids in isolation usually have minimal cardiovascular effects, but they can cause vasodilation and bradycardia by increasing vagal nerve tone in the brainstem (Egan, 2023). These effects are more pronounced in patients with underlying conditions i.e. congestive heart failure or hypovolemia, where the risk of significant hypotension and bradycardia is higher (Bokoch & Su, 2023).

 

Clinical consideration:

  • Close monitoring of vital signs: respiratory and heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation and capnography are essential for patient safety when opioids and benzodiazepines are given together (Egan, 2023). Capnography can detect early signs of hypoventilation or apnea.
  • All doses must be titrated carefully to achieve desired effect, taking into consideration patient population and procedural stimuli (Lobb et al., 2018). Begin sedation with the lowest effective dose and increase gradually as needed.
  • Extra caution is needed for higher risk populations: elderly or patients with renal or hepatic impairment, or multiple co-morbidities (Bokoch & Su, 2023; Egan, 2023). They are more susceptible to pronounced synergistic effects.
  • Flumazenil reverses the action of benzodiazepines, while naloxone reverses action of opioids (Bokoch & Su, 2023; Egan, 2023). Having both reversal agents readily available is essential. Repeat dosing maybe required due to short half life of reversal agents (Bokoch & Su, 2023)

 

References:

Bokoch, M. P., & Su, P. P. (2023). Intravenous anesthetics. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 107-124). Elsevier.

Boon, M., van Dorp, E., Broens, S., & Overdyk, F. (2020). Combining opioids and

benzodiazepines: effects on mortality and severe adverse respiratory events. Annals of

palliative medicine, 9(2), 542–557. https://doi.org/10.21037/apm.2019.12.09

Egan, T.D. (2023). Opioids. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 125-142). Elsevier.

Lobb, D., Clarke, A., & Lai, H. (2018). Administration order of midazolam/fentanyl for moderate dental sedation. Journal of dental anesthesia and pain medicine, 18(1), 47–56. https://doi.org/10.17245/jdapm.2018.18.1.47

Yeo, X. H., & Shehabi, Z. (2023). Effectiveness and safety of dentist-led conscious sedation using fentanyl with midazolam in dentistry: a five-year retrospective service evaluation. British dental journal, 1–6. Advance online publication. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41415-023-5889-3

Responses.Author: Junia Isaac
Responses.Content:
Hi Reneerose, I really enjoyed reading your detailed and insightful post! You've done an excellent job outlining the pharmacodynamics of combining opioids and benzodiazepines for sedation, as well as the potential risks associated with their synergistic effects. Your discussion on the interplay between these agents' sedative and analgesic properties really stood out to me, especially in terms of how they are commonly used during procedural sedation.

 

Your points about the heightened risk of respiratory depression when these two drug classes are combined are particularly important (Bokoch & Su, 2023). This has me thinking more about how clinicians can balance the need for effective sedation with minimizing these risks, especially in patients with pre-existing respiratory conditions. In practice, how do you think we can best mitigate this risk when titrating doses in high-risk populations like the elderly or those with comorbidities? Would the use of adjunct agents, such as dexmedetomidine, help in providing sedation without exacerbating respiratory depression?

 

Lastly, I appreciate that you brought up the need for close monitoring and the use of reversal agents like flumazenil and naloxone (Bokoch & Su, 2023; Egan, 2023). It made me wonder, how frequently are these reversal agents required in routine clinical practice, and do you think the reliance on them could influence decisions on whether to use this drug combination for sedation in certain populations? This topic has made me reconsider the complexities of using these drugs together and think deeper about the strategies we use to maintain patient safety during sedation.

 

References 

Bokoch, M. P., & Su, P. P. (2023). Intravenous anesthetics. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 107-124). Elsevier.

 

Egan, T.D. (2023). Opioids. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 125-142). Elsevier.

Responses.Author: Reneerose Ong
Responses.Content:
Hi Junia,

Thank you for your thorough response. I agree that dexmedetomidine is an excellent adjunct, offering sedation without suppressing airway reflexes or ventilation. Its additional analgesic properties are also a valuable benefit, especially in reducing opioid requirements.

While specific statistics on the frequency of reversal agent use in clinical practice are hard to pinpoint, it is well-known that flumazenil (for benzodiazepines) and naloxone (for opioids) are generally reserved for emergent situations or when a patient unintentionally reaches deeper sedation levels (Wong, 2022). These agents require careful postoperative monitoring due to the potential for "bounce-back" effects after the reversal wears off, while the sedative or opioid may still be active (Wong, 2022).

 

Reference:

Wong M. (2022). Reversal Agents in Sedation and Anesthesia Practice

for Dentistry. Anesthesia progress, 69(1), 49–58.

https://doi.org/10.2344/anpr-69-01-09

Responses.Author: Adrian Harris
Responses.Content:
Hi Reneerose and Junia,

 

Thanks for sharing this valuable insight on the potential synergistic sedative effects of opioids combined with benzodiazepines, as well as the safety considerations and mitigating risk when using them during procedural sedation.  This brings up an interesting talking point about the varying thoughts around the use of benzodiazepines for pre-sedation.  As Junia alluded to in her response, how best can we mitigate risk with the use of benzodiazepines for sedation within the elderly population?  For the AAs at my institution, anecdotally there appears to be two varying schools of thought around the use of midazolam in the elderly patient requiring sedation in the perioperative setting.

 

There is one camp that follows the idea that midazolam use in elderly patients leads to increased risk of post-operative confusion, delirium or cognitive impairment. and will avoid its use for pre-sedation or during any type of procedural sedation.  Their belief is supported by theory that midazolam use in the elderly can cause exacerbated amnestic action at the g amino butyric acid (GABAA) receptors, resulting in post-procedural cognitive changes with some residual amnestic effects (1).  At my institution, these AAs will avoid the use of midazolam for sedation in elderly patients, instead relying on other non-benzodiazepines (like dexmedetomidine, for example).

 

The other camp believes wholeheartedly in its use, especially for patients who are on some form of anti-anxiety medication at home, and who don’t have a diagnosis of dementia or cognitive impairment.  These AAs have seen no post-procedure neurological concerns in the stable elderly population who received pre-sedation or procedural sedation using midazolam. 

 

Interestingly, a recent study published in the Journal of Clinical Anesthesiology, evaluated premedication using midazolam in patients 70 years of age and older, and reviewed their incidence of post-operative delirium (2).  After receiving intravenous midazolam administration prior to an induction with general anesthesia, 1973 patients who were undergoing non-cardiac procedures were determined to have experienced no delirium post-operatively (2).  The study concluded with the suggestion that lower-dose (3.75mg) midazolam could safely be used in the elderly population for a non-cardiac surgery with no expected increased risk of post-operative delirium (2).

 

While the risk may not outweigh its benefits, pre-medicating or procedural sedation in the elderly with midazolam should be considered with caution.  As discussed by Reneerose above, the known synergistic effects between benzodiazepines and other CNS depressants are well-known (3) and such, the use of benzodiazepines should always be carefully contemplated, especially in the elderly population. 

 

 

1. Walling A, Caspray D. Effects of benzodiazepines after procedures in elderly patients. Am Fam Physician [Internet]. 2002 [cited 2024 Oct 8] 9:online-only-. Available from: https://www.aafp.org/pubs/afp/issues/2002/0501/ol2.html

 

2. Zarour S, Weiss Y, Kieselevich Y, Iacubovici L, Karol D, Shaylor R et al. The association between midazolam premedication and postoperative delirium - a retrospective cohort study. J Clin Anesth. [Internet]. 2024 Feb [cited 2024 Oct 8] 92:111113. Available from: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37280146/

 

3. Egan TD. Opioids. In: Miller’s basics of anesthesia. 8th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier Inc; c2023. p. 125-142.

Responses.Author: Ryan Smith
Responses.Content:
Thank you Reneerose, Junia and Adrian for your thoughtful insights into benzodiazepine and opioids used concurrently. Indeed caution and vigilance is required when administering these agents together. It prompted me to recall a somewhat novel benzodiazepine Remimazolam and its use in conscious sedation procedures such as endoscopy with concurrent short acting opioids such as alfentenil.
In a recent RCT comparing Remimazolam (RM) vs propofol with concurrent alfentenil infusions for hysteroscopy, the RM group showed a statistically significantly higher mean arterial pressure, heart rate and mean SpO2 (n=208). A Dixon’s regression model was used post hoc to determine an ED50 of 0.244mg/kg.<sup>1</sup> In a slightly smaller RCT published the same year for patients undergoing laparoscopic urologic surgery, RM with remifentanyl vs desflourane with remifantanyl, the RM group showed improved post operative pain scores.<sup>2</sup> Several other small to medium scale RCTs and anecdote are emerging, and clearly this drug needs to find its place in anesthesia providers experience. It is encouraging to note that as time has marched forward in anesthesia over the past decades, the pharmaceutical regimens available are making pre, peri and post operative care for the patients better and safer.
References
1. Huang B, Nan-Ping L, Gang-Kai T,  Liang Na. Effectiveness and safety of remimazolam combined with alfentanil in hysteroscopic examination: A prospective, randomized, single-blind trial. Medicine. 2024 Apr; 103(15) 376
2. Lee C, Lim J, Hong H, Yu H, Lee H. Effect of Remimazolam on Pain Perception and Opioid-Induced Hyperalgesia in Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Urologic Surgery—A Prospective, Randomized, Controlled Study. Medicina. 2024 Jan; 60(1): 123.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content: Answering Junia’s question on reversal agents, they should be rarely used, especially in procedural sedation administered by the Anesthesia Care Team. I agree with Renee that these agents are reserved for emergent situations and should not be used to justify administering large boluses of anesthetics simply because reversal agents are available. However, I recognize that procedural sedation performed in other settings by different healthcare professionals may involve a higher frequency of reversal agent use. I have been invited to provide talks on procedural sedation and the use of reversal agents in some departments.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Tenzing Choedar
Responses.Content:
Thank you Reneerose for reminding us that the clinical synergy observed between benzodiazepines and opioids when administered concomitantly is a significant consideration in the realm of anesthesia and sedation. The combined pharmacodynamic effects of these two classes of drugs result in an enhanced level of sedation and analgesia, a phenomenon often described as supra-additive. This means that the overall sedative and analgesic effects exceed the simple sum of the individual drug effects, making it imperative to adjust dosages accordingly. As such, this interaction underscores the importance of caution when administering multiple sedatives together. Dosing strategies should err on the conservative side, as the potentiation of their effects can lead to profound sedation, respiratory depression, or other adverse outcomes if not carefully managed as you have pointed out nicely.

To add to Adrian’s comment, I definitely err on the side of caution when I have very elderly patients in my cathlab. Especially if they are over 85 years old, I tend to only start of with 0.5mg of Midazolam with 12.5-25mcg of Fentanyl depending on their co-morbidities, medication hx and baseline vitals. However, there are times when I wish I could switch up some of these medications when I am providing conscious sedation; but as a nurse I am limited to my intra procedure medication orders which are usually only midazolam and fentanyl. During my literature review, I found multiple studies looking at the synergistic effects of multiple sedatives when given together. Babu et al. (2024) investigated the synergistic effects of dexmedetomidine in combination with propofol, comparing the results to a group that received only propofol for patients undergoing ERCP. In the study, 80 patients aged 18 to 60 were randomly assigned to two groups. The dexmedetomidine + propofol group (group DP) received an initial infusion of dexmedetomidine at a dose of 1 mcg/kg in 100 mL of saline over 10 minutes, while the propofol group (group P) received 100 mL of plain normal saline over the same time. Both groups were then administered a bolus dose of propofol at 1 mg/kg for sedation. Following this, a continuous infusion of propofol at 50 mcg/kg/min was maintained throughout the procedure. If signs of inadequate sedation or analgesia were observed, a rescue bolus of 20 mg of propofol was given to patients in both groups. They found that dexmedetomidine, when used as an adjunct to propofol, improved sedation quality, reduced the need for additional propofol, and contributed to more stable hemodynamics in patients undergoing ERCP. Another study by Nejati et al. (2011) conducted a prospective, double-blind, randomized trial comparing the ketamine/propofol (ketofol) combination with midazolam/fentanyl (MF) for procedural sedation and analgesia (PSA) in emergency department patients requiring treatment for deep lacerations or bone fractures. They found that there were no signiﬁcant differences in sedation time but ketofol group had deeper sedation and analgesia, however the rate of desaturation was greater in the MF group. Emergence phenomenon did occur in 9 patients out of 31 with one requiring intervention with midazolam.

Ultimately, I am recognizing that balanced anesthesia is the optimal approach. With a variety of drug combinations available—such as midazolam with fentanyl, ketamine with propofol, and dexmedetomidine with propofol—having a deep understanding of the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of these commonly used agents is essential. Equally important is a comprehensive awareness of the patient’s medication history and comorbidities. Coupled with a well-prepared strategy for managing potential adverse effects, this knowledge enables us to select the most appropriate sedative regimen, ensuring both efficacy and safety in procedural sedation. For example, if a pt has a very high risk of aspiration or respiratory compromise, then ketofol is probably the way to go.

 Reference:

Babu, T. R., Kumar, M. R. A., Anup, N. R., & Shetty, S. M. (2024). Dexmedetomidine as an adjunct to propofol in patients undergoing elective endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreaticography - A double-blind randomized controlled study. Journal of Pharmacy & Bioallied Science, 16(Suppl 1), S399-S402. https://doi.org/10.4103/jpbs.jpbs_617_23

Nejati, A., Moharari, R. S., Ashraf, H., Labaf, A., & Golshani, K. (2011). Ketamine/Propofol versus Midazolam/Fentanyl for procedural sedation and analgesia in the emergency department: A randomized, prospective, Double‐Blind trial. Academic Emergency Medicine, 18(8), 800-806. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1553-2712.2011.01133.x

 Cheers, 

Tenzing

Question: Question 6: Describe the significant differences in clinical effect when opioids are given at sedative versus induction doses.

Responses.Author: Tenzing Choedar
Responses.Content:
The physiological and subsequent clinical effects of opioids is well studied. Opioids play a critical role in the management of perioperative care and are essential for effective pain control during and after surgery. Opioids bind primarily to mu receptors which are mainly found in the Central Nervous System (CNS) and since the nervous system significantly impacts the functioning of the whole body, the pharmacodynamic effects of mu opioid agonists are evident across various organ system (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022; Egan, 2023). For the sake of this discussion, focus will be maintained solely on the acute phase of the clinical effect with sedative dosing versus induction dosing which can vary significantly.

 

Firstly, it is vital to understand that the therapeutic benefits of opioids as pain relievers and their potential to cause respiratory depression are inherently linked, making it difficult to separate their effectiveness from their harmful side effects. Depending on the specific clinical situation and treatment objectives, some of these broad effects may be regarded as either beneficial or harmful (Egan, 2023). Listed below are the highlights of opioids effect on the physiological system apart from pain suppression. These effects are dose-dependent, with higher dose having more exaggerated effects.  

 

Respiratory System:

  • Depress respiratory rate and can also affect tidal volume depending on the dosage via mu(μ) receptor mediated hyperpolarization of the neurons in the respiratory control centre in the brainstem. At low doses, tidal volume may remain steady or rise slightly due to chemoreflex compensation, but it decreases at higher doses because of reduced phrenic motor neuron activity which innervates the diaphragm.
    • Gradual opioid administration allows central chemoreceptors to adjust to rising CO2 levels, minimizing the risk of apnea, whereas rapid boluses can cause apnea before PaCO2 rises to stimulate compensatory increases in ventilation.
  • Inhibits the hypercapnic and hypoxic ventilatory reflexes via hyperpolarization of the central and peripheral chemoreceptor neurons. This impairs the feedback response to the respiratory control centres leading to insufficient responses to hypercapnia and hypoxemia.
  • Inhibits upper airway protective reflexes (Bateman, Saunders, & Levitt, 2023; Egan, 2023)
  • Can increase airway resistance due to its direct effect on bronchial smooth muscle and indirectly via histamine release (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022)

 

Central Nervous System:

  • Dose dependent CNS depression ranging from drowsiness, sedation to sleep (At high enough doses, mu opioid agonists generate significant delta wave activity on an electroencephalogram (EEG), resembling the brain wave patterns typically seen during natural sleep.
  • Increases Intracranial Pressure (ICP) with decreases in cerebral blood flow and cerebral metabolic oxygen requirements despite maintenance of an unchanged Paco2.
    • This may be due to autoregulatory decreases in cerebral vascular resistance due to decrease in Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP). This rise in ICP can be avoided by maintaining adequate MAP.
  • Induces miosis via stimulation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus of the oculomotor nerve but not seen with Meperidine, rather causes mydriasis (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022; Egan, 2023)

 

Cardiovascular System:

  • Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR) – Can decrease SVR via vasodilation of the blood vessels by decreasing the activity of the vasomotor centers in the brainstem affecting preload and afterload. Has less direct effect on the blood vessels (Egan, 2023).
    • Morphine contributes to more histamine release which can also decrease SVR, whereas Fentanyl derivatives do not cause the release of histamine.
    • Impairs compensatory sympathetic nervous system response leading to orthostatic hypotension and syncope.  (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022).
  • Heart rate (HR) – Can decrease HR by directly increasing vagal nerve tone in the brainstem. Fentanyl has greater bradycardic effect than morphine however Meperidine can rather increase the HR due to its atropine like qualities. 
    • In neonates, Fentanyl administration has to be carefully monitored to avoid bradycardia because cardiac output is mainly dependent on HR. (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022; Egan, 2023).
  • Ultimately, drop in blood pressure more pronounced in patients with higher sympathetic tone such as patients with shock, heart failure, hypertension and hypovolemia (Egan, 2023).

 

Musculoskeletal System:

  • Rapid large boluses of opioids particularly fentanyl and its derivatives can cause generalized muscle rigidity making bag and mask ventilation during induction of anesthesia difficult due to vocal cord rigidity and closure.
    • The inhibition of GABA release in the striatum, along with increased dopamine production, is likely responsible for the opioid-induced rise in skeletal muscle tone
  • Clonic skeletal muscle movements (myoclonus) can occur during opioid administration and can appear similar to grand mal seizures (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022; Egan, 2023)

GI

  • All opioids can induce nausea and vomiting in approximately 26% of patients (Arthur & Hui 2018). This is due to stimulation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the area postrema on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brain.
    • Can be exacerbated by movement, more pronounced in day surgery patients.
  • Can cause delayed gastric emptying and post operative ileus. Constipation is common with acute and chronic opioid use.

 

Sedative dose effect:

Opioids are a fundamental part of medications used during procedural sedation; however, they are seldom used alone but in conjunction with benzodiazepine. Sedative dosing for fentanyl as per Lexicomp Inc, 2024, are:

-0.5 to 1 mcg/kg every 2 minutes until desired level of sedation and analgesia achieved for adults and adolescents

-1 to 2 mcg/kg/dose; administer 3 minutes before the procedure; maximum dose: 50 mcg/dose; may repeat 1/2 original dose every 3 to 5 minutes if necessary; titrate to effect, for infants.

The clinical effects of sedative opioid dosing can range from moderate analgesics control leading to heighten comfort, respiratory depression and drowsiness to sleep. Therefore, The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) (2018), recommends strict monitoring of Patient’s Level of Consciousness, Ventilation (capnography) and Oxygenation, and Hemodynamics (HR and BP). Furthermore, ASA (2018) recommends the use of supplemental oxygen as meta-analysis of multiple randomized controlled trial (RCT) showed association with reduced risk of hypoxemia in procedural sedation. Acarel, Yildirimturk, and Yapici (2021) found in their study with patients who underwent electrical cardioversion with the use of midazolam and fentanyl at standard doses provided adequate sedation without any adverse effects on hemodynamic. Fentanyl derivatives are known to cause minimal effect on the cardiovascular hemodynamic other than HR via direct effect on the vagal nerve tone in the brainstem. However, it is to note that combining benzodiazepine with fentanyl can sometime exacerbate respiratory depression and lower blood pressure with effects more pronounced in elderly population, high BMI and OSA (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022; Egan, 2023).

 

Induction dose effect:

When opioids are administered at **induction doses**, their clinical effects are significantly more pronounced compared to sedative doses. Opioids are rarely used as sole induction agents, rather as an adjuvant to other induction agents. The primary reason for the use of opioids for induction is to blunt the sympathetic responses to tracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy as it inhibits upper airway protective reflexes (Cummings III & Naguib, 2022; Egan, 2023). Fentanyl has been mainly used as a sole induction agent in cardiovascular surgery patients as it has minimal effects on patient’s hemodynamics and sympathetic surge can have a negative impact in patients with coronary artery disease, heart failure etc. A great review article by Faine et al. (2024) looked at the effects of fentanyl dosing as a sole induction agent in cardiac surgery patients and the subsequent hemodynamic effects. They found that in one study moderate dose of fentanyl (10-25mcg/kg) produced 90% successful induction without significant changes in hemodynamics during the 10 minutes post intubation period. Similarly with another study looking at 50mcg/kg bolus dosing (high dose), loss of consciousness occurred within 45 seconds without significant hemodynamic changes during 5 minutes post intubation. Chest wall rigidity occurred in 27% in one study using only fentanyl as sole induction with high dose (300mcg-400mcg/min until unconscious). Overall, the review article concluded that generalization to today’s practice is limited as studies were conducted 30 years ago and high doses of fentanyl are not used for induction in today’s practice. Moreover, patients’ awareness were not assessed after the use of paralytic agent and risk of prolonged respiratory depression remains post-surgery. Joo et al. (2004) found that using remifentanil (5mcg/kg) as a primary induction agent with midazolam (70mcg/kg) and glycopyrrolate (0.2mg) offered a rapid, predictable loss of consciousness with no ability to recall, providing cardiac stability and effectively blunting the hemodynamic response to tracheal intubation. Bradycardia was prevented due to the use of glycopyrrolate. Due to its short duration of action, remifentanil may be a viable alternative to fentanyl for anesthesia induction in patients with heart disease, making it particularly useful in this high-risk group with decrease risk of post-operative respiratory depression.

 

References:

Acarel, M., Yildirimturk, Ö., & Yapici, N. (2021). Bateman, J. T., Saunders, S. E., & Levitt, E. S. (2023). Understanding and countering opioid-induced respiratory depression. British Journal of Pharmacology, 180(7), 813–828. https://doi.org/10.1111/bph.15580

 

Cummings III, K. C., & Naguib, M. A. (2022). Opioid agonists and antagonists. In P. Flood, J. P. Rathmell, & R. D. Urman (Eds.), Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in Anesthetic Practice (6th ed., pp. 206-245). Wolters Kluwer.

 

Egan, T. D. (2023). Opioids. In M. C. Pardo (Ed.), Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed., pp. 107-124). Elsevier.

 

Faine, B. A., Carroll, E., Sharma, A., & Mohr, N. (2024). Rapid sequence intubation, is it time to find an alternative induction agent? A narrative review. SAGE Publications. https://doi.org/10.1177/08971900231197501

Responses.Author: Adrian Harris
Responses.Content:
Hi Tenzing! Thanks for sharing this super insightful look into the clinical effects of sedation vs induction dose opioids. Your information has given me a better appreciation of the dose effect of the various opioids, especially on hemodynamics, and some of the adverse of unwanted effects that come along with them.

 

I was recently speaking to one of the AAs at my site about how a particular opioid is selected for a case.  They mentioned that the reason for desired effect (what they need it for) and the duration of desired effect (how long the case is) can both play a large part in the decision process. When researching that, I came across some information that I can share with respect to the timing of effect, as that can also impact on the choice of opioid and its clinical effect. 

 

There is evidence that front-end kinetics of opioids, which is how they act right after bolus administration, can also impact on its clinical effect (1). Depending on the opioid choice, when given by bolus there may be a delay in clinical effect time before the expected response is seen, known as latency to peak effect (1).  For example, if the desired effect of an induction dose opioid is the blunting of sympathetic response to an emergent intubation, then morphine as an example, may not be the optimal opioid of choice, as the latency to peak effect will be longer than a drug such a remifentanil or fentanyl (1).  

 

Additionally, the back-end kinetics, which is the time to a clinically relevant concentration degradation or decay (1), can also play a role in the choice of opioids.  If the desired clinical effect is a longer duration of analgesia with less dissipation of drug, then bolus dose remifentanil may not be the long-term drug of choice, for example during longer procedures (unless you want to keep providing bolus after bolus).  However, if the desired clinical effect is maximal opioid effect but for much shorter case duration, there may be benefit from remifentanil infusion as an example.  With that example, the time to context-sensitive half-time concentration will be much shorter, despite even a longer infusion-time, as compared to other opioid infusions (1).

 

The front-end and back-end kinetics of various opioids via bolus or infusion are illustrated in Figure 1 below.  They are a helpful add-on to the already well-described clinical effects of sedation vs induction doses summary you've provided.  

Cheers,

Adrian. 

 

Figure 1. Opioid pharmacokinetics. Bolus: Front-end and back-end time after injection vs % of peak concentration (top); infusion: front-end duration of infusion vs concentration (middle); infusion back-end infusion duration vs time to context-sensitive half-time (bottom) (1)

 

1. Egan TD. Opioids. In: Miller’s basics of anesthesia. 8th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier Inc; c2023. p. 125-142.

Responses.Author: Meera Sathananthan
Responses.Content:
Hi Tenzing and Adrian, Thank you both for your insights. Adrian, your explanation on how timing affects patient outcomes, such as minimizing complications during induction, was very helpful! Tenzing, your discussion on opioid effects provided an excellent foundation. Adrian, your points on latency to peak effect and context-sensitive half-time add valuable depth to opioid selection, especially in high-risk situations like cardiac arrest or major trauma which we frequently encounter at St. Michael's. At St. Michael's, remifentanil is commonly used for induction and maintenance in the OR, particularly in patients with cardiac issues. Its rapid onset, short duration, and context-sensitive half-life make it ideal for procedures requiring quick anesthesia adjustments, helping blunt sympathetic responses during intubation like you mentioned Tenzing and maintain hemodynamic stability (1). Remifentanil's predictability and rapid recovery are beneficial for procedures like neurosurgery and cardiac surgeries, where precise sedation helps avoid complications like hemodynamic instability and improves recovery (2). Additionally, its minimal residual effects facilitate postoperative care, especially when prompt neurologic assessment is needed (2). One downside of remifentanil to make note of is its potential to cause hyperalgesia, which is an increased sensitivity to pain after discontinuation. This can be managed with multimodal analgesia, such as using non-opioid analgesics like acetaminophen or NSAIDs to improve pain control and reduce opioid requirements (2). This is important to keep in mind when thinking of post-operative care. Remifentanil is rapidly metabolized, providing predictable sedation without the prolonged sedation or respiratory depression seen with morphine or fentanyl, which facilitates faster recovery and prompt neurologic assessments (1). Recently, I have even seen it implemented in our neurosurgical ICU to help a patient manage their pain and keep them calm while intubated, while still allowing nurses to perform neuro checks when necessary. Remifentanil also helps maintain hemodynamic stability, particularly in cardiac patients, by allowing precise anesthesia control and minimizing blood pressure or heart rate fluctuations (2). Its shorter latency to peak effect is beneficial during induction, particularly in critical situations requiring rapid reduction of the body's stress response (1). Hopefully these additional tidbits about remifentanil are helpful! Thank you both again for the discussion :) Sincerely,
Meera **References** 1. Egan TD, Newberry, C. Opioids. In: Pardo MC Jr, Miller RD, editors. Basics of anesthesia. 7th ed. Philadelphia (USA): Elsevier; 2018. p. 123-142.
2. Cummings K 3rd, Naguib MA. Opioid agonists and antagonists. In: Flood P, Rathmell JP, Urman RD, editors. Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anesthetic practice. 6th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2022. p. 217-250.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Great discussion on opioids!

 

Opioid is a special class of drug as it can be used at any level of the sedation continuum, from minimal sedation to general anesthesia.  It is a great example to illustrate the dose-dependent clinical and side effects, as mentioned by Tenzing.  Different doses of opioids can achieve a certain level of analgesia. However, their impact on the respiratory system, cardiovascular system, and degree of consciousness can vary greatly. Moreover, Adrian reminded us that the onset and duration of the effects also differ.

 

I want to take this opportunity to review the Ramsay Sedation Score, which we use to monitor the levels of sedation at the University Health Network.

 

Level

Characteristics

1

Awake, anxious, agitated, or restless

2

Awake, cooperative, oriented, and tranquil

3

Drowsy, with response to commands

4

Asleep, brisk response to glabella tap or loud auditory stimulus

5

Asleep, sluggish response to tactile stimulus

6

No response to firm nail-bed pressure or other noxious stimuli

 

For sedation, at levels 2 – 3, very low doses are used to maintain the respiratory drive.  The patient is drowsy because there is a depression of consciousness, but the patient can still cooperate and follow commands.

 

In general anesthesia, level 6, the patient is unconscious with no response to noxious stimuli.  There is a dose-dependent depression in ventilation through decreased respiratory rate and sensitivity to carbon dioxide.  This causes an irregular breathing rhythm and potentially complete apnea. The cough reflex is inhibited, and airway obstruction can occur. 

 

Tenzing pointed out that during the induction of general anesthesia, we give a small bolus of Fentanyl 1 – 3 minutes before intubation to blunt circulatory responses evoked by direct laryngoscopy.  We also give intermittent IV boluses to supplement inhaled anesthetics during maintenance, utilizing a balanced anesthesia approach.  Large doses of Fentanyl can be used as the sole induction agent in cardiac surgeries to provide protective effects for the heart.  They reduce the hemodynamic and stress response in patients by blunting the sympathetic nervous system response triggered by the vasodilation induced by other anesthetic agents.

Question: Question 7: Describe the significant differences in clinical effect when local anesthetics are given at local versus regional doses.

Responses.Author: Paula Watkis
Responses.Content: See attached document

Attachments.filename: Differences in clinical Effects of Local Anesthesia at LOCAL VS REGIONAL DOSE.docx

Responses.Author: Ryan Smith
Responses.Content:
Paula Thanks for your summary of the differences of local anesthetic given at local versus regional dose ranges.  As I have virtually no experience in this field apart from anecdote I found an interesting meta analysis worth sharing in trying to learn about this topic. A recent (2022) moderately high powered (n=3665) meta analysis of high (>0.1%), low (>0.08% to ≤0.1%) or ultra‐low (≤0.08%) buvipicaine given via epidural for labour was conducted yielding interesting results. The ultra-low subgroup had statistically significantly higher incidence of vaginal delivery, improved motor score and no difference in c-section incidence and top-up needed. Overall the maternal and neonatal outcomes were similar or better in the ultra-low group.1 Given the small but present risk of local anesthetic toxicity, it begs the question as to the direction of peri-natal anesthetic care and drug strength choice for this particular patient group. Certainly avoiding the possible sequealae of higher dose local anesthetic administration is favourable and it will be interesting to watch over time if our practice changes with emerging data.
-Ryan Reference: 1. Halliday L, Kinsella M, Shaw M, Cheyne J, Nelson SM, Kearns RJ. Comparison of ultra‐low, low and high concentration local anaesthetic for labour epidural analgesia: a systematic review and network meta‐analysis. Anaesthesia. 2022 Aug; 77(8): 910–918.

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam

Question: Question 8: Describe the role of lipid resuscitation in the treatment of local anesthetic systemic toxicity. Provide the initial bolus dose and the maintenance dose.

Responses.Author: Janet Rozek
Responses.Content:
Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is an adverse effect of local anesthetics. This complication occurs when there is an excess plasma concentration of the drug in the body. The plasma concentration of local anesthetics is defined by the rate of the drug in the systemic circulation relative to the redistribution to other tissue sites and the ability to clear the drug by metabolism. The most reported incidents of LAST are during epidural anesthesia and accidental direct intravascular injection of local anesthetic during peripheral nerve block anesthesia. (Maheshwari & Nuguib 2018). Systemic toxicity of local anesthetics involves the central nervous system and the cardiovascular system. The signs and symptoms of LAST can vary from restlessness, vertigo, tinnitus, to slurred speech and muscle twitching to other significant effects with high plasma concentrations including systemic hypotension, seizures, apnea, cardiovascular depression and coma. Patients often report the delusion of imminent death (Maheshwari & Nuguib 2018).

Neurologic symptoms

Cardiac symptoms

Seizures

Cardiovascular collapse

Altered mental status

Hypotension

Tinnitus

Arrythmia (Asystole, bradycardia, Ventricular arrythmias)

Metallic taste

 

Perioral numbness

 

 

Management of LAST:

  1. Stop injection of local anesthetic at the fist indication of toxicity
  2. Call for help, get LAST treatment kit
  3. If respiratory distress, apnea or loss of consciousness
    1. Bag valve mask airway, deliver 100% oxygen, assist ventilation as needed
  4. Ensure good IV access
  5. Is there is seizure activity administer
    1. Midazolam IV 0.5 to 1mg increments
    2. Propofol IV 10 to 20 mg
  6. Immediately administer lipid emulsion (20%)
    1. Bolus 1.5mL/kg over 1 minute (approx. 100ml)
    2. Continuous infusion 0.25-0.5mL/kg/min until stable
    3. Can repeat bolus dose if symptoms continue
  7. Monitor for further seizure activity
  8. Manage arrest as necessary
  9. Monitor in ICU for at least 12 hours

(Dority, 2015)

The mechanism of action of lipid emulsion is not entirely understood, but research supports the lipid sink theory which describes the lipid emulsion as a lipid depot where highly fat-soluble drugs are absorbed and cleared from the tissues and organs. The lipid molecules bind to the highly fat-soluble local anesthetic and significantly improve cardiovascular and neuro function of the patient. Below is an example of how lipid emulsion works in our bodies (Liu et al., 2021).

                                                                                                                                                (Liu et al., 2021)

 

References:

Dority, J. (2015). Neurologic Events. In D.M. Gaba & A. Burden. Crisis Management in

Anesthesiology (2nd ed., pp 243-249). United Kingdom: Elsevier Health Sciences.

Liu, Y., Zhang, J., Yu, P., Niu, J., & Yu, S. (2021). Mechanisms and efficacy of intravenous

lipid emulsion treatment for systemic toxicity from local anesthetics. Frontiers in medicine, 8, 756866. https://doi.org/10.3389/fmed.2021.756866

Maheshwari,K & Naguid,M. (2018). Local Anesthetics. In P. Flood, J. P. Rathmell, & R. D. Urman

Responses.Author: Kelly Gram
Deena Kurilsky
Responses.Content:
Thank you for your explanation Janet. It was very informative and highlights the urgent nature of treatment of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST).

Regarding the use of local with peripheral nerve blocks. An important tip to remember when assisting with a peripheral nerve block that will help minimize the risk of accidental intravascular injection. Is to perform a negative aspiration test to confirm the needle is not in the blood vessel before injecting. Simple, yet very effective.

 

Additionally, epinephrine can be added to the solution. The addition of epinephrine will cause vasoconstriction, this will help keep the drug in the intended area, help to prolong the anesthetic effect and reduce the rate of systemic absorption.

 

Toda, C., & Naguib, M. A., (Eds.). (2022). Basic Principles of Pharmacology. In P. Flood, J. P. Rathmell (Eds.), Stoelting’s pharmacology & physiology in anesthetic practice (6th ed., pp 971-973). Wolters Kluwer

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Great contribution, everyone! Thanks, Janet, for providing the list of signs and symptoms so that we can recognize and treat LAST early. Kelly, the pneumonic is a nice touch! Pneumonic is so useful, and you will learn many more in the next semester. I want to add that the ester local anesthetics such as Procaine, Chloroprocaine, and Tetracaine cause fewer potential risks for LAST because of their rapid metabolism by plasma cholinesterase.  They are less likely to gain significant concentration, which leads to toxicity. However, decreases in plasma cholinesterase quantity or activity will slow the elimination of these drugs.  On the other hand, the amide local anesthetics such as Lidocaine, Bupivacaine, and Ropivacaine are metabolized slower by the liver and therefore, it is more likely to cumulate in the plasma and increase the risk of LAST. Regarding the dosage of intralipid, according to the American Society of Regionals Anesthesia and Pain Medicine (ASRA) 2020 Guidelines, it depends on the patient’s weight. In patients over 70 kg, it is recommended to bolus 100 mL IV over 2-3 minutes, followed by an infusion of 200-250 mL over 15-20 minutes. In patients under 70 kg, it is recommended to IV bolus 1.5 mL/kg over 2-3 minutes, followed by an infusion at 0.25 mL/kg/minute (1). Like any other adverse event, the best treatment is prevention. Other than the good practice prevention techniques mentioned by Deena, it is also very important to be cognizant of the maximum allowable dosage for each local anesthetic plain and with Epinephrine. 
Here is a list of the maximum dose for the most commonly used local anesthetics:
  • Lidocaine: 5 mg/kg plain; 7 mg/kg with epi
  • Bupivacaine: 3 mg/kg
  • Ropivacaine: 3 mg/kg
  • Mepivacaine: 5 mg/kg plain; 7 mg/kg with epi
  • Chloroprocaine: 12 mg/kg
  1. Neal JM, Neal EJ, Weinberg GL. American Society of Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine local anesthetic systemic toxicity checklist: 2020 version. Regional Anesthesia & Pain Medicine. 2021;46(1):81-82. Available from: https://doi.org/10.1136/rapm-2020-101986

Responses.Author: Paula Watkis

Question: Question 9: What is the role of nitrous oxide in general anesthesia? What does the current literature and practice suggest about its use?

Responses.Author: Janelyne Mandegarian
Responses.Content:
Nitrous oxide (N2O) plays an important role in general anesthesia (GA) as it has multiple functions even though it is the least potent inhalation anesthetic. It works differently from the other volatiles anesthetics by being an NMDA – receptor antagonists, whereas the others potentiate GABAA receptors. Knuf and Maani (2023) state the anesthetic effects are produced through non-competitive NMDA inhibition in the central nervous system.

N2O and GABA modulators act synergistically to generate an amnesia and hypnosis effect (Cook & Hemmings, 2023). Because of the high concentration of 104% to achieve MAC it is normally combined with other volatile anesthetics that are more potent and can not endure being the sole anesthetic agent which makes it a worthwhile adjunct in anesthesia. N2O is administered at about 60-70% of the gas mixture and affects the alveolar volume and uptake into the lungs. N2O diffuses out of the alveoli quickly, thus the remains of the inhalation agents in the alveoli are more concentrated, this is called concentration effect. Second gas effect as seen on Figure 1 (Cook & Hemmings, 2023) improves the speed of onset of volatile gases. The onset of action is approximately 2 to 5 minutes and when combined can achieve general anesthesia and decreases the risk of awareness intraoperatively (Knuf & Maani, 2023).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Figure 1: When nitrous oxide is delivered at high concentrations it will diffuse the N2O out of the alveoli. Then, the decreasing alveolar volume will concentrate the remaining anesthetic gases, which is called the concentration effect and second gas effect. The effects of such will produce a high partial pressure which increases the rate of induction.

Note. Adapted from Miller’s basics of anesthesia, by Padro, 2023, p. 89. Copyright 2023 by Elsevier.

 

Conversely, the same principle can also be used for emergence from anesthesia causing a “washout” of the brain because it has a short elimination half time (Cook & Hemmings, 2023). During emergence diffusion hypoxia can occur because of the low ventilation with air and the nitrous oxide. N2O transfers into the alveolus, diluting the oxygen concentration and impairs the transfer into the blood which causes the hypoxia (Brown & Syned, 2016).

N2O has analgesics properties that are effective with treatment for severe and chronic pain. It can also weaken hyperalgesia from remifentanil (Flood et al, 2022). The analgesic effect is produced from endogenous opioids that stimulate opioid receptors which mimic morphine and produces anxiolytics effects through GABA activation. N2O is commonly seen with dental procedure, where is it known as “laughing gas” because it leads to euphoria (Knuf & Maani, 2023).

Nitrous oxide can be mixed 50% with oxygen to achieve these effects and can be very beneficial in the obstetrical ward but in accordance with American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), N2O can cross the placenta but is swiftly eliminated from neonates when they take their first breathes. They also note it should not be combined with other sedatives, hypnotics and opioids for increased risk of maternal hypoxemia and mothers can resume breastfeeding after they have recovered from anesthesia because of its short elimination half life (Knuf & Maani, 2023).

 N2O should be used with caution for surgeries with enclosed compartments generating gases. Whether conditions or surgeries, nitrous oxide can diffuse faster into gas filled cavities because of the high partial pressures. Patients with vitamin b12 deficiency can yield neuropathy and megaloblastic anemia due to the inhibition of methionine synthetase. Also, concern was raised for increased cardiovascular morbidity from possible increase of homocysteine levels (Cook & Hemmings, 2023).    

 

Cook, D., Hemmings, H. (2023) Inhaled Anesthetics in Pardo, M. Miller’s basics of anesthesia (8th ed.,96,97). Elsevier.

Flood, P., Shafer, S. L., Ardin, S. B. (2022) in Flood, P., Rathmell, J. Stoelting's pharmacology & physiology in anesthetic practice (6th ed., 373). Wolters Kluwer.

Brown, S.M., Sneyd, J.R. (2016). Nitrous oxide in modern anaesthetic practice. BJA Education (16, 3, 87–91). https://doi.org/10.1093/bjaceaccp/mkv019

Knuf, K., Maani, C.V. Nitrous Oxide. [Updated 2023 Aug 28]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532922/

Responses.Author: Teresa Nguyen
Responses.Content:
Hi Janelyne,

 

Thank you for your answer. I appreciate your incorporation of the “second gas effect” and the explanation. To add on, another critical point that is applicable in patient care is that when a patient is emerging from anesthesia, they may experience diffusion hypoxia, as you mentioned. According to Knuf and Maani (2023), once nitrous oxide administration is stopped, the patient should receive 100% oxygen to combat the adverse effects of diffusion hypoxia.

 

In regards to exercising caution with nitrous oxide, examples of surgeries/procedures that involve enclosed compartments are contraindicated: closed-loop bowel obstruction, pneumocephalus, pneumothorax and middle ear surgery (Pardo, Miller, & Stoelting, 2023).

 

In your post, you mentioned that nitrous oxide has analgesic properties, therefore making it an effective treatment for severe and chronic pain. Can you clarify and further explain how nitrous oxide is related to endogenous opioids (as you mentioned that the analgesic effect from nitrous oxide is produced from endogenous opioids)?

 

Furthermore, my inquiry question for you is that if nitrous oxide is related to opioid receptors, is nitrous oxide equally effective for treating acute pain as it is with chronic pain? How about if you were to consider that the patient with chronic pain had a medical history of taking oral opioids? Chronic use of opioids leads to tolerance and limits clinical use (Morgan & Christie, 2011).

 

 

 

References

 

Knuf, K., & Maani, C. (2023). Nitrous oxide. In Bookshelf.

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532922/

 

Morgan, M., & Christie, M. (2011). Analysis of opioid efficacy, tolerance, addition, and

dependence from cell culture to human. British Journal of Pharmacology, 164(4), 1322-1334. https://doi: 10.1111/j.1476-5381.2011.01335.x

 

Pardo, M., Miller, R. D., & Stoelting, R. K. (2023). Miller’s Basics of Anesthesia. Elsevier.

Responses.Author: Junia Isaac
Responses.Content:
Hi Janelyne and Teresa, Thank you both for your thorough insights into nitrous oxide’s (N2O) role in general anesthesia, especially with the explanation of the second gas effect and diffusion hypoxia. I’d like to expand on the conversation by discussing a few additional aspects of nitrous oxide. Janelyne highlighted the analgesic properties of nitrous oxide via endogenous opioid stimulation, I found it interesting that nitrous oxide’s analgesic effect may also involve the activation of noradrenergic pathways, specifically in the periaqueductal gray area of the brain (Fujinaga & Maze, 2002). This dual mechanism of action, through both opioidergic and noradrenergic systems, suggests that nitrous oxide could offer broader applications in managing different types of pain. Teresa’s question about its efficacy in treating acute versus chronic pain is quite relevant here. Could the involvement of these pathways suggest that nitrous oxide may be more effective in certain acute pain settings compared to chronic pain, particularly for opioid-tolerant patients? Another emerging discussion is the neurotoxicity associated with prolonged or repeated exposure to N2O, especially in the pediatric and elderly populations. Evidence from Davidson and Sun (2018) suggests that prolonged or repeated exposure to nitrous oxide in pediatric populations may result in neuronal apoptosis and long-term cognitive deficits (Davidson et al., 2016). This is particularly concerning for vulnerable groups, which raises the question of whether nitrous oxide should be used more conservatively in these populations. Lastly, building on the idea of balancing benefits with risks, Teresa mentioned surgeries involving enclosed compartments where nitrous oxide is contraindicated. Interestingly, there’s also literature suggesting that N2O could exacerbate air embolisms due to its rapid diffusion into air-filled spaces (Junghans et al., 2000; Munson & Merrick, 1966). Could this be a reason why nitrous oxide use is reduced in certain high-risk surgeries? With all these factors in mind (dual mechanisms of analgesia, neurotoxicity, and surgical contraindications), do you think we’ll see a decline in nitrous oxide use in the coming years, or does its unique set of benefits still justify its regular use in clinical practice?

Responses.Author: Mary Johnsy Joseph
Responses.Content:
Hi Janelyn, it is very informative, you explained in detail the important role of

nitrous oxide (N2O) in general anesthesia. N2O is an anesthetic and analgesic gas, it acts on

multiple supraspinal and spinal targets and has utility in a wide range of clinical situations

(Hosseinian et. al, 2018)

        Hosseinian et. al., (2018) stated that N2O is one of the earliest anesthetics in use. It has

retained its role as a versatile agent with anesthetic, analgesic, and sedative roles owing to

its efficacy and relative safety. N2O is a viable alternative to more invasive procedures for

labor analgesia.

        Knuf and Maani (2023) explained that compared to other anesthetic agents, nitrous oxide

causes minimal effects on respiration and hemodynamics. It leads to decreased tidal volume and

increased respiratory rate but minimizes overall minute ventilation. Nitrous oxide leads to direct

myocardial depression, but nitrous oxide's sympathetic stimulation reduces this effect, and the net

effect is minimal. Unlike other volatile anesthetics, nitrous oxide has no muscle relaxation

properties.

        Hi Teresa, I had the same question that how nitrous oxide is related to endogenous opioids. I

found it interesting that the analgesic effects occur by releasing endogenous opioids that act on

opioid receptors: its analgesic actions are like morphine (Knuf & Maani, 2023). The anxiolytic

effects are through GABA-A activation. Nitrous oxide has a central sympathetic stimulating

activity that supports blood pressure, systemic vascular resistance, and cardiac output (Knuf &

Maani, 2023).

        Hi Junia, to clarify about the contraindications, I found that the blood: gas partition

coefficient of nitrous oxide is 30 times greater than that of nitrogen. Because of this, N2O will

enter gas-filled spaces more than thirty times faster than nitrogen. intrapleural gas volumes

doubled within 10 min and tripled in 30–45 min. In contrast, intrapleural and intestinal gas

volumes remained constant or decreased with halothane and oxygen administration. Therefore,

pneumothorax, bowel obstruction and pneumopericardium are considered contraindications to

N2O (Lew, et. al., 2018).

Responses.Author: Kurt Protacio
Responses.Content:
Hey Janelyne,

 

Thank you for your thorough research on helping us understand the use of nitrous oxide in general anesthesia. I really appreciate everyone’s responses thus far, and would like to add on another reason why nitrous oxide can be beneficial in today’s practice.

 

In addition to what Mary highlighted, nitrous oxide is a choice many anesthesiologists will consider for a general anesthesia case as it is a viable, inexpensive, versatile agent with anesthetic, analgesic, and sedative properties. In 2014, a study was published, highlighting the overall effect of using nitrous oxide for general anesthesia in patients with perioperative cardiovascular risk (dubbed ENIGMA-II trial). After one year, they concluded from their sample size of nearly 6000 patients that had non-cardiac surgery, there was no increase in mortality, cardiovascular complications such as myocardial infarction, and even surgical-site infections compared to patients with cardiovascular history (Myles et al., 2014). This was a huge step forward in the decision to use nitrous oxide more often, however, most literature tends to disagree with the use of nitrous oxide on cardiovascular patients undergoing cardiac surgery as, Janelyne and the rest have pointed out, nitrous oxide can produce a decrease in myocardial contractility, decreasing overall cardiac output, and increases the systemic vascular resistance. This can lead to further cardiovascular complications such as heart failure. Therefore, the use of nitrous oxide, based on the literature, should be avoided in patients with congential heart disease (CHD) where pulmonary arterial pressure tends to be higher than the normal population, and coronary bypass graft surgery (CABG), where monitoring hemodynamics can be troublesome and can require strategic monitoring using emergency drugs (Neidecker, 2001). Therefore, although inexpensive, we have discussed on the previous threads of the use of nitrous oxide as a multimodal anesthetic, and should remember that it has a negative inotropic effect due to its direct effect on the heart.

References

Myles, P. S., Leslie, K., Chan, M. T. V., Forbes, A., Peyton, P. J., Paech, M. J., Beattie, W. S., Sessler, D. I., Devereaux, P. J., Silbert, B., Schricker, T., & Wallace, S. (2014). The safety of addition of nitrous oxide to general anaesthesia in at-risk patients having major non-cardiac surgery (ENIGMA-II): a randomised, single-blind trial. The Lancet, 384(9952), 1446–1454. https://doi.org/10.1016/s0140-6736(14)60893-x

 

Neidecker, J. (2001). Nitrous oxide: use in cardiovascular risk patients. Best Practice & Research Clinical Anaesthesiology, 15(3), 429–435. https://doi.org/10.1053/bean.2001.0178

Responses.Author: Phoebe Lam
Responses.Content:
Thanks, everyone, for sharing your perspective on the usage of nitrous oxide.
The role and practice of nitrous oxide have been debatable for many years.  The appeal of nitrous oxide is its analgesic properties and its use in dental clinics and labour and delivery.  Nitronox and Entonox are popular brands with a 50/50 oxygen-nitrous oxide mixture.  In contrast, some anesthesiologists argue against nitrous oxide due to its side effects, such as diffusion hypoxia and rapid diffusion into closed air spaces, causing increased pressure and volume, as mentioned above. Other than the closed air spaces that have been suggested, nitrous oxide can diffuse into endotracheal tube cuffs and increase the pressure against tracheal mucosa, causing unnecessary potential airway damage. Also, because nitrous oxide deactivates vitamin B12, which is necessary for DNA synthesis, we should use it with caution in pregnant patients during the first two trimesters of pregnancy and those with a deficiency in vitamin B12.   Furthermore, it is important to note that nitrous oxide is a potent greenhouse gas that contributes to global warming. Muret et al. (2019) examined its environmental impact and commented that nitrous oxide has about 300 times higher global warming potential than carbon dioxide. Using 50% nitrous oxide at a fresh gas flow of 1 L/min has an equivalent greenhouse potential as driving an average-sized car for 120 km. With its long list of adverse effects mentioned in our discussion and the fact that many other drugs work just as well or better for the maintenance of anesthesia, nitrous oxide has lost its popularity in general anesthesia.  This is evident by the removal of the emergency tank of nitrous oxide at the back of anesthesia gas machines in most operating rooms nowadays. References

Environmental impacts of nitrous oxide: No laughing matter! Comment on Br J Anaesth 2019; 122: 587–604. British Journal of Anaesthesia, 123(4), e481–e482. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bja.2019.06.013
